thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: kambo rambo
content: User #95309 463 posts kambo rambo Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RbQPFm posted 2009-May-18, 4:29 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RbQPFm posted 2009-May-18, 4:29 am AEST O.P. Just wondering whats involved in a grad program, i'm getting alot of mixed answers from googling. I'd like to know how long, what kind of useful things do i learn, what my gpa should be like or better yet a link to a website with useful information. Forgot to mention, i'm a Computer Scientist to be graduate.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Meehan
content: User #278679 159 posts Meehan Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RbQPQh posted 2009-May-18, 9:13 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RbQPQh posted 2009-May-18, 9:13 am AEST I hate to give a generic answer but...it really depends on the program. In answer to your questions: Programs generally range from 9-24 months in length. Within that period most companies offer rotations through different departments of the organisation. If it's a Generalist program then you might be doing rotations through areas you aren't necessarily all that interested in. If it's a Specialist program then it's more likely that you'll be doing rotations through departments relevant to your studies Useful things you learn...again depends on whether it's a Generalist or Specialist program. You'll most likely undergo technical training specific to your job (I'm not really sure what that involves for computer science... you could find more of that specifically on company websites) as well as soft skill training which is more about general business-related skills like organisational networking and leadership and how to write business reports GPA is generally a minimum credit average – i.e. >65. Some companies ask for higher depending on the requirements of the program, but as a general rule it's credit average Some websites which might be handy are www.graduatecareers.com.au and www.unigrad.com.au

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: ls.
content: User #223578 140 posts ls. Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RbQPRT posted 2009-May-18, 9:26 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RbQPRT posted 2009-May-18, 9:26 am AEST From my understanding its identifying talented individuals who the org believes can become future leaders. So when you enter a grad program essentially you are expected to advance to managerial positions within a couple of years. You're given a lot more training than non-graduates (leadership, motivational training). You also have a bigger network, given you'll have a mentor and because you've done rotations, networking events etc. So in other words you're handfed a lot of opportunities which non-graduates would most likely have to be real standouts to be able to achieve. Whilst you can still achieve all the things a graduate can achieve without the program, it'll definitely provide you with the best opportunity straight out of uni.

author: yudan
content: User #278562 176 posts yudan Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RbQQ6z posted 2009-May-18, 3:50 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RbQQ6z posted 2009-May-18, 3:50 pm AEST apply in your final year. most companies actually offer positions to students around April/May in their final year. thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Meehan
content: User #278679 159 posts Meehan Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RbQQ7f posted 2009-May-18, 3:53 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RbQQ7f posted 2009-May-18, 3:53 pm AEST Ultimately the decision is yours, but I would suggest applying in your final year. It'll take a weight off your shoulders knowing that you have a job waiting for you when you graduate. Alternatively, you could wait and apply the year after you graduate, and use that extra year to gain work experience and rack up some volunteer work. Most company application forms ask you to list each of your completed subjects and the grade you received, and they determine your current GPA based on that information. If you've done reasonably well in your first 2-3 years at university, GPA should be the least of your worries when it comes to graduate applications.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Sooners
content: User #10991 1844 posts Sooners Whirlpool Enthusiast reference: whrl.pl/RbQRVD posted 2009-May-18, 7:29 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RbQRVD posted 2009-May-18, 7:29 pm AEST A graduate program in its truest sense is basically a planned/structured program for taking someone with little or no work expereince and giving them work experience so then they can add value to the org. In short, there's a plan in place! This is different to an entry level role where I had to learn either everything myself or from another consultant while on the job. What someone had posted earlier about it being for "future leaders" isn't necessarily true. Obviously they want all employees to stay and become future leaders, but they're primarily there as a means of providing you with a structured intro into the working world.

author: SheikYerbouti
content: User #86389 11022 posts SheikYerbouti Whirlpool Forums Addict reference: whrl.pl/RbQWgr posted 2009-May-19, 1:03 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RbQWgr posted 2009-May-19, 1:03 pm AEST ls. writes... From my understanding its identifying talented individuals who the org believes can become future leaders. HAHAHAHAHAh yeah right. Show me all the senior managers who started as grads in that company, and I'll possibly believe that it CAN happen. But for each one of them, I'll show you 10 who joined the business later in life having worked elsewhere first. Many comments on how good grad programs are, come from grads whose entire fulltime work experience is their one grad program in one place. Its taking in people with a degree but no clue, and giving them that clue, so they are moulded exactly as the business wants them. You come out with a degree and knowing how to work in that organisation, how all the parts work etc. Similar to gaining work experience elsewhere and then applying to that business – in that case you already have a proven track record in that job/industry so there's no need for a 1-2 yr program to teach you how things work.

content: User #289765 5 posts SpikeTheSpider Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rb1w8y posted 2009-Sep-29, 9:45 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rb1w8y posted 2009-Sep-29, 9:45 am AEST Qantas has just opened theirs for 2011 pre-registration. Jumps in there peeple, their recruitment process starts next March.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: jobcrunch
content: User #314628 1 posts jobcrunch Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rb1QoP posted 2009-Oct-4, 2:32 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rb1QoP posted 2009-Oct-4, 2:32 pm AEST I agree with the above comments in it being more structured. I went through a graduate program for 2 years in a non-IT job. They had leadership training, softskills training, and you had mentors as well through the company. We also had a lot of technical training as well, to ramp us up in the first 6 months. We had formal training through a universty too. I understand from comments from managment that because of all the training and investment, they don't make their return on you until after 2 years. Which is typically when most young people who have come through a grad program decide to leave (2-4 years). I'd also advise you to check non-graduate program roles. The reason being that graduate programs attract the most candidates, and hence have the most competition. Its what a lot of graduates dream of – working for that big company. I did the same thing. But there's a ton of opportunities in SME's as well, and i encourage you to explore that option.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: coolaid29
content: User #319018 21 posts coolaid29 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rb6OPn posted 2009-Dec-16, 8:04 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rb6OPn posted 2009-Dec-16, 8:04 pm AEST I haven't gone through the typical graduate program, I went straight into an engineering role where I was mentored (and spoonfed lol) by more senior engineers I've worked with lots of engineers who started out or were in graduate programs, and depending on industry, the rotation, experience, pay is very different. How graduates are seen is so dependant on the culture of the company. My feeling has been that in the oil industry, graduates are seen as leaders of tomorrow. The upside is graduates are given lots of opportunities to move around and understand how the company works as a whole. The downside is as many of these graduates start out as technical people, they take away with them a lot of technical knowledge each time they move. This means that yes, you have excellent people all being managers, but very little technical experts who have been around for 5+ years. That said, all is not lost as these engineers eventually come back around and end up in their old bosses jobs. This observation is based on working alongside grads from 3 oil giants (I've contract for). In other industries I've worked with (consulting, government run processing facility, private explosives company) sometimes, graduates were treated like poo. They were the gophers of the 'real' engineer. In one company, for 3 years, they retained their "Graduate Process Engineer" title, and until they finished their rotation, they were not treated like 'real' engineers. I felt sorry for these as they were usually given the most tedious of the technical jobs and having to constantly prove yourself. I feel that good grad programs have flexibility in rotation, well structured mentoring/support system and regular appraisal/reviews. Pay-wise, grad programs range from 40k to 100k, again dependent on industry.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: writey
content: User #286365 20 posts writey Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rb8YGK posted 2010-Jan-19, 10:02 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rb8YGK posted 2010-Jan-19, 10:02 am AEST Just an FYI. If you google "graduate program" you are also going to get the American common definition of that term, which is graduate school, ie post grad such as a Masters program. Graduate program in Australia is not further study, it is a formal structured entry type of work for a recent graduates. Pretty much what most people have answered in this forum.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rb80ez posted 2010-Jan-19, 3:36 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rb80ez posted 2010-Jan-19, 3:36 pm AEST AI-Expert writes... Its where you get a 25% pay increase after being there after your first year. That is not a typical example.. unfortunately. In the current economic climate, you need to appreciate having a job you can enjoy, before you worry about your first increase. Here is my '2 bob': Grad Programs in Australia are often a structured medium to ease school leavers in to the 'real world'. Dependent on your industry, this might be as simple as having someone oversee you for 3 months, or through to something far more structured. I'm in engineering, and for me that was doing non-technical project work and odd jobs to start with, to get my head around the industry, terminology and what to expect. It also gives you time to find your feet, and work out which area, specialisation, or approach you want to take with your career. For us it's 3-4 years, because that is how long it takes to get Chartered Professional Engineering Status ('CP ENG') in most cases. In most cases, yes, you do get the 'crap' little tedious roles that no one else wants. An odd job here and there isn't bad, and it helps you learn more about the business and industry. I have a friend who was on a grad program, but his only roles involved doing other people's boring tasks, and he missed out on his rotation. This is an example of poor management and is not a graduate program. He changed companies after the first year, and is better for it. When considering a graduate program: 1) Know how long the program is for, and if it is flexible 2) find out if there are rotations, and to WHERE (i.e. are you going to be sent to a remote area for a year?) 3) Find out if there is a mentor or buddy system (VERY useful when first starting out) 4) Apply for all jobs you are legitimately interested in, regardless of GPA/grade requirement, but make sure you know their core business well, and be confident without being cocky. 5) Ensure there will be 'continuous professional development' throughout your graduate program, and throughout your career. These are the best companies to work for, although sometimes the sacrifice is that the pay is not in the top percentile. WHY? — because it is better to have 10 years of experience, rather than having one year of experience, repeated 10 times.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RcbvgH posted 2010-Feb-25, 7:10 am AEST edited 2010-Feb-25, 7:14 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RcbvgH posted 2010-Feb-25, 7:10 am AEST (edited 2010-Feb-25, 7:14 am AEST) Viscount writes... How soon is too soon to mention this job on my resume? You would put it as your 'current employer', in terms of employment experience i.e where you list companies; but if you haven't achieved anything notable within this new position, it may not be work putting into the section of 'work' experience – i.e. where you elaborate your work skills experience for the various positions you have held. The questions are: "What can I do now, that I couldn't do before I started?" (for a job just after you finish uni), or "What skills have I used in this role, that might put me above peers applying for this next role?" – Then it is worth while putting it in. As soon as you put something on a resume, be prepared to talk about it and provide further information. If the current position is not relevant to your studies, you can still use it as experience, through giving an example on how you have acted on, or advised on safety or management. A good one is giving an example of how you coped and overcame a difficult situation, and have learned from it. The examples are probably more suited for during the interview, unless you have a real 'eye catcher', that would draw their attention to your resume in particular. If you are having trouble with lack of work experience, also note board and other positions held on noteworthy clubs, associations & community groups that demonstrates responsibility. It is never to late to join a group like LIONS ( http://www.lionsclubs.org/EN/find-a-club.php ) or ROTARY, and be involved in the community and hold a position on the board. Good luck with it all. [edit: add quote]

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rcbvhv posted 2010-Feb-25, 7:20 am AEST edited 2010-Feb-25, 8:17 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rcbvhv posted 2010-Feb-25, 7:20 am AEST (edited 2010-Feb-25, 8:17 am AEST) kunju writes... graduate programs in civil engineering Assuming you are referring to the employer graduate program, rather than further study (after the Bachelor of Engineering), many employers will not consider people with more than 2-3 years of industry experience for a graduate role within that industry. 2 years of work experience I am not able to start my career due to lack of local experience Does this mean, you already have the Bachelor of Engineering (Civil)? – But have had the 2 years of work experience outside the industry? If that is correct, then you should apply for the graduate positions. Lack of local experience – you will need to elaborate. If you have an overseas qualification, you can apply for 'recognition' for your degree through the government for free. However, Engineers Australia does not recognise this equivalency. Basically, if you have the qualification, and the language, you should be able to use SEEK.COM.AU or equivalent to find the jobs. People apply for jobs interstate & overseas frequently. If you don't have the qualification, or have great difficulty with the language of the country, then you have an immensely large study load ahead if you wish to work as an Engineer in that country.

author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RccBR7 posted 2010-Mar-13, 9:33 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RccBR7 posted 2010-Mar-13, 9:33 pm AEST Guirguis Rezk writes... I'm an biomedical engineering graduate Good luck. I am not overly familiar with mainstream employment in that field. If you're not interested in research with a university or equivalent, it may be worth your while to get a second qualification – i.e. pharmacy or nursing – assuming you are interested in that side, having taken on biomed. That may help you with future employment in engineering in that field. Keeping in mind, that not all fields or employers offer 'graduate' positions. You may have to remove 'graduate' from your search criteria, as some fields will throw you in head first. Especially those, which are not overly common as you figuratively have to wait for someone to die before a position becomes available.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: ElementZero
content: User #353578 19 posts ElementZero Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RciqB6 posted 2010-May-31, 11:43 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RciqB6 posted 2010-May-31, 11:43 pm AEST Viscount writes... I was just wondering – I just got a job last week developing for a market research/marketing company. How soon is too soon to mention this job on my resume? Apart from a year long Uni industry project I don't have any hands on experience, and this is something that this new job will provide while I finish my last few subjects at University. I would like to mention it in the grad apps that I am currently submitting, but I think it might be too soon? I assume this job you are starting is a part-time "studentish" job and not a professional career? I'd put it on my resume if it's definitely in the bag, because by the time they come to interview you you should be a few weeks, if not months, into it and can elaborate on you do at work better by then. So if you're starting in June, putting "June 2010 – Present" or something into your resume would be my suggestion. Always present the best possible image of yourself while still maintaining the truth.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RciFhH posted 2010-Jun-3, 1:32 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RciFhH posted 2010-Jun-3, 1:32 pm AEST Dr Incandenza writes... does it mean that I am guaranteed to become CEO of said financial institution one day? You can read the fine print, but graduate programs do not usually have any progression beyond the level above graduate. The whole point of most graduate programs, is to simply help graduates 'establish' themselves in their respective industries. You are almost guaranteed to not become the CEO of the company you start in. If it is a very big firm, you will have a lot of politics in your way, and not to mention the imports from other companies. You will also probably require an MBA to consider a role like CEO.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RciFjx posted 2010-Jun-3, 1:38 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RciFjx posted 2010-Jun-3, 1:38 pm AEST 1800 writes... is there anychance of getting into a grad program with like A 4.5gpa There is a very good chance. Although, with whom may be limited depending on your industry. Some firms are very particular with minimum GPA's. These days though, many firms (not all industries) realise that common sense, and knowing how to solve problems, and dealing with people (clients, customers etc) is more important than a university mark. The ultimate weapon would be both GPA and the above mentioned traits, as well as being confident in the interview, without being cocky.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rcj5dX posted 2010-Jun-21, 11:26 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rcj5dX posted 2010-Jun-21, 11:26 am AEST cytoprism writes... Now that I ve made into a grad program what happens afterwards ? This depends on the conditions of your employment. i.e. are you on a 2 year contract? – and you will have to re-apply after that time? Or have you signed something that states that you will be a manager of some group at the end of your completion? (I imagine this would be rare?) – The trick here is simply to ASK. Keeping in mind, unless it is written into your contract, things can change. Many graduates are taken on as full time permanent employees, and will simply stay on after the program runs its course (i.e. no bonuses or financial acknowledgement). This may be VERY different in some industries. Note I am most familiar with engineering. Do not get your hopes too high for 'what comes next' (regarding management), but keep a clear idea of where you want to go as you will need to 'drive' your career. Sometimes you may be required to be more persistent to get what you want. After my graduate program comes to an end, do I get a pay hike or am I offered a managerial position ? Would it be a good idea to finish a grad program with one company and then apply to a different company and expect to be paid a lot better ? It is not a good idea to 'stick it out' if you are not benefiting from it (i.e. learning a great deal). In the case of engineering graduate programs, they usually are fairly vague. For example they often include 'professional development' talks, training, rotations, and often engineers will often 'drop off the program' when one of the following occurs: You have been in the company more than 4 years (or what ever your company defines) You progress, and your title / pay is beyond that of graduate, You acquire your Chartered Status (Which usually takes about 3.5 years) Many companies offer a bonus and a slight pay rise for those who acquire chartered status. Other employers will simply hold any potential advancement and pay rise, until Chartered status is acquired. In many cases (depending on your industry), you will not get a managerial position at the end of the program. This is because, by in large, a graduate program is to establish a graduate into an industry that they are not familiar with. My understanding of the intent is that when you have finished the graduate program, you should be a 'useful employee' for the more complicated intermediate roles. [i.e. work unsupervised with minimal to no instruction] In terms of money / interest etc, it is very much an 'as you go' self moderation. If you get to a point of stagnation where you are not learning anything, or if you know in all honesty that you are not being acknowledged for the level of work / time etc that you put towards the company, then it is the time to leave. Do not rush the " expect to be paid a lot better ? " query. The biggest issue for graduates who get to the point of 'boredom' or just want more money, is bunny hopping to new jobs while the industry is good, to get more pay. Their pay then was greater than their abilities, and they were the first to go (termination of contract, redundancies etc) when the times got tough. I encourage other areas of industry to put forward their 'typical graduate program' examples, as it is likely to differ greatly from the above.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: -Invictus-
content: User #384714 1969 posts -Invictus- Whirlpool Enthusiast reference: whrl.pl/RcrHJx posted 2010-Sep-27, 7:24 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RcrHJx posted 2010-Sep-27, 7:24 am AEST Is it possible to defer the commencement date of graduate program by 2-3 weeks ?

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/Rcto0w posted 2010-Oct-6, 3:02 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rcto0w posted 2010-Oct-6, 3:02 pm AEST I am new writes... Is it possible to defer the commencement date of graduate program by 2-3 weeks ? That is all dependent on the type and structure of the program. For example in some companies, a graduate program is as simple as you being recognised as 'new', and you commence with simple tasks, and under the direction of a mentor. In that case there shouldn't be any issue with when you commence. At the other extreme, some companies have a mass-intake and do a 1 week orientation program, followed by other forms of development. I imagine that they would prefer you do not miss the group orientation.

author: State Alchemist
content: User #386705 164 posts State Alchemist Participant reference: whrl.pl/RcC4a1 posted 2011-Jan-28, 5:11 pm AEST edited 2011-Jan-28, 5:53 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RcC4a1 posted 2011-Jan-28, 5:11 pm AEST (edited 2011-Jan-28, 5:53 pm AEST) Corinthia writes... Keeping in mind, that not all fields or employers offer 'graduate' positions as some fields will throw you in head first. Especially those, which are not overly common as you figuratively have to wait for someone to die before a position becomes available. Just wondering, there's a lot of talk on these forums regarding graduate programs available for candidates in fields such as engineering, commerce and IT, but how applicable is this to science? From what I've gathered, science has a different progression and application in terms of a career due to a variety of factors (eg. type of industry, qualifications, type of major/specialisation etc.), but my question is whether graduate programs are available for science graduates in the same way they are for most other fields as stated before? Is it possible for science students to gain work experience in an industry environment (like engineering students, for example) during their studies? Or is this one field where it just isn't possible? I've found that some companies (eg. Pharmaceutical, food/beverage, chemical industries, enviro etc.) offer graduate programs or something of the like, but at times they do specify minimum qualifications (eg. Honours, Masters etc.). So what actually counts as a 'graduate' when it comes to science? Is the term always reliant on the level of qualification required for the position in this case? I would be much appreciated if anyone could answer any of these questions.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: ohmy!
content: User #269760 1373 posts ohmy! Whirlpool Enthusiast reference: whrl.pl/RcDFI7 posted 2011-Feb-6, 8:54 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RcDFI7 posted 2011-Feb-6, 8:54 pm AEST blindsighted writes... but how applicable is this to science? I do a science degree and it there are hardly any graduate programs for it. I am hoping that you have noticed that it is extremely competitive for whatever positions there are to begin with. That is the main reason why I transferred into a double degree after my first year. I didn't want to be a unemployed graduate. There are some places like accounting firms whom might take you as a generalist, but you won't be able to gain any experience which is related to i.e chemistry. I have a lot of friends who have graduated and the majority of them are now studying further or working in Target and Woolworths. True story. edit: Oh and I should mention, if you are head set on going down the science pathway, you'll need to go and do further study. My friend's brother did his honours then did his PhD. Then he got a job at Novartis, but thats only like part time, he's got to work other odd jobs on his days off.

'Sure ways' of giving yourself a good chance at employment in Science is (a) do a double degree (IT, Engineering, Business etc) (b) Become a high school maths/science teacher (c;) Plan to do masters/PHD and make research your life. I have seen all three of the above from science. I have also seen people become taxi drivers. The ideal jobs, (in any industry) you probably have to know someone, or wait for someone to die.

author: saturn28
content: User #422524 11 posts saturn28 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RcNpt1 posted 2011-Jun-20, 7:24 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RcNpt1 posted 2011-Jun-20, 7:24 pm AEST from the above discussions, which is better? an entry level role or a graduate program?

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Corinthia
content: User #74479 186 posts Corinthia Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RcQHxJ posted 2011-Aug-7, 7:55 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RcQHxJ posted 2011-Aug-7, 7:55 pm AEST saturn28 writes... which is better? an entry level role or a graduate program? All depends on the industry you are referring to, and the company you are interested in. Being employed in an entry-level environment with supportive networks / mentors around you, can be better than a bad graduate program that is limited, with no real structure or support. You are best to speak to recent graduates in the companies you are interested in, to find out what / if any support is given to new-starters. Some Graduate programs are excellent — but there are far more companies with programs that aren't the best. Usually you will sacrifice a higher starting wage, to start a company with a good program — but it will pay off in the end. [Keeping in mind that I am only really familiar with the Engineering industry]

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Apache757
content: User #433400 8 posts Apache757 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/Rc6R3v posted 2012-Mar-6, 8:53 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rc6R3v posted 2012-Mar-6, 8:53 am AEST A grad program is great because it makes it easier for you to ask more questions that otherwise you may feel withheld in asking. People accept that the "grad" won't know everything and are happy to help you. In terms of what is involved in a grad program... well, that's really hard to say because every company does things differently. One standout program that I've seen is the ABB grad program, which funnily enough doesn't get that much exposure. Sample ABB Grad program > ( http://www.abbaustralia.com. au/cawp/auabb506/8b1aae28b2d 68ae1ca2573f6001a8d57.aspx ) ABB 2013 Grad Program Thread ( /forum-replies.cfm?t=1875344 ) That first link gives you a great idea of one type of grad program. Some companies will offer one single job or project for the duration of your grad program, but unless you know 100% that you want to be there.. you won't find it very enjoyable and will probably get bored. Basically go through each company's website and if there isn't enough info, then call up HR and they should be happy to help. If you can't find HR's number, then try and get to a careers fair. If all else fails, send an email to their contact us page. But do your research! Enjoy :)

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Apache757
content: User #433400 8 posts Apache757 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/Rc6TqK posted 2012-Mar-6, 10:30 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rc6TqK posted 2012-Mar-6, 10:30 am AEST CellarDoor357 writes... Wow, do you know anyone who worked there Apache? Program looks good, but do you have to change roles every rotation? Yea I know a few people there doing the grad program. Every rotation you would be working in a different area of ABB working on a different project. But from everything I have been told, its great to go through because then you understand how the whole business runs which then gives you a massive advantage. Not just because you know how all the parts fit together, but also because you have an opportunity to network with people in all the parts of the company which is extremely beneficial. And 4 months is a good period of time where you can get some experience and move on before it gets boring. It's also quite flexible in terms of what projects you can work on so you can push to do certain projects and work on certain teams. Hope that helps!

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: foxtwo
content: User #281670 43 posts foxtwo Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RdaixY posted 2012-Apr-26, 8:28 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RdaixY posted 2012-Apr-26, 8:28 pm AEST JohnnyCougarSoviet writes... Can you apply for more than one graduate program at a time? Yes! Many people apply for multiple graduate programs. It depends what industry you're in, but you can apply for many many graduate programs – so if you have the time and effort to put into each of them (and to keep track of them all) do it! There is nothing wrong with applying for multiple programs, and hopefully you should get a few offers at the end of it. As the age-old saying goes: "Don't put all your eggs in one basket."

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Christiano Ronaldo
content: User #307213 74 posts Christiano Ronaldo Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RdbiXw posted 2012-May-11, 2:45 pm AEST edited 2012-May-11, 2:51 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RdbiXw posted 2012-May-11, 2:45 pm AEST (edited 2012-May-11, 2:51 pm AEST) A grad progam is a long and elaborate process to find the best quality staff at the cheapest price to live through canberra winters to do mainly filing or answer phones. Most public servants often confuse grads with indigenous cadets, or work experience school kids. Essentially, the mindset from most public servants (who just start their careers 2 to 3 levels higher in the deparment without going thru a grad program and often with no real qualifications), is that graduate programs are opportunities for kids transitioning from school to their first job in maccas etc. No effort is spent to educate general staff that graduate program candidates actually have skills, qualifications or even work experience. Mature aged grads are often thought of as 'slow starters', and unspoken opinions appear to be, hmmm he must not have had the opportunity to study when he was young, he must have gone to jail and become reformed then went to Uni, or he must have been a refugee who learnt to read and write in Australia and is now looking for his first employment role. When advertising graduate programs however, departments spare no expense and the intense competition leads each and every subsequent grad cohort to think the following: 1) Competition for places was exceptionally difficult this year. 2) We must be really special because it was really really difficult to get in.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: library_of_knowledge
content: User #544705 87 posts library_of_knowledge Participant reference: whrl.pl/RdCt7x posted 2013-Jun-14, 3:52 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RdCt7x posted 2013-Jun-14, 3:52 pm AEST kambo rambo writes... Just wondering whats involved in a grad program, i'm getting alot of mixed answers from googling. I'd like to know how long, what kind of useful things do i learn, what my gpa should be like or better yet a link to a website with useful information. Forgot to mention, i'm a Computer Scientist to be graduate. Hi, I'm a graduate with Suncorp and I guess I can answer your question. A graduate is someone who just finished their university studies and has a fresh eye on everything in a work place. Companies invest in graduates because they think graduates challenge the norm, and has the ability to make great changes. Different companies will offer different graduate positions and also different lengths of contract, but most are 2 years. Although most companies have a very specific structure in recruiting graduates, once you get in the door there really isn't much structure in teaching you. What you learn and how your career progresses depend strongly on yourself. Regarding GPA, again, different companies value GPA more and some less. Some companies hire you for your personality and attitude, whereas some see your GPA being the most important qualifying factor. In saying that, you should have at least a GPA of 5. Let me know if you got any other questions, I'll try answer as best I can.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: auras818
content: User #561895 6 posts auras818 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RdWy4B posted 2014-Apr-11, 11:17 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RdWy4B posted 2014-Apr-11, 11:17 am AEST Don't make the mistake that I did! I was told that I was very "lucky" and "talented". Actually I was gullible. I was forced to work for a long time in an unlucky untalented bad job and I couldn't quit because they had tricked me into signing a fixed duration contract. I couldn't leave until the expiry of the contract. About "Psychometric Testing" and other online tests they make you do — for *some* graduate programs, it doesn't matter how you answer. Sometimes they don't even look at the results of your tests. So why do they make you do these online tests if they don't care about the results? They make us do these tests in order to make us feel special and privileged when we seem to pass the test. We worry about the test, later we receive an email saying "Congratulations!! You passed the test and you are successful onto the next round!" But sometimes they send the congratulations/success email to everyone — yes EVERYONE passes the test. It's all slowly leading to the ultimate goal of convincing you to stay in a boring or bad job for a much longer time than you would normally choose to. Another goal is reducing recruitment costs by convincing a large number of people to attend group interviews — this is much cheaper to run than individual interviews. But the difficulty with group interviews is that many people don't bother attending the group interview, they know it's usually a waste of time. In order to convince people to attend the group interview, the recruiter uses a long fake application process so that by the time the group interview date arrives, you feel that you have invested so much time/effort into the whole process that you feel you should attend the group interview. The recruiters don't care about wasting the time of hundreds of people. Sometimes they ask you to submit an video of yourself. They may or may not watch the video you make. A friend of mine uploaded an insulting video but got selected for the next round anyway. Most likely my friend was not really "selected" — actually the recruiter "selected" everyone. They were just trying to convince a whole bunch of graduates to attend a huge "group interview".

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: aimlessly
content: User #432134 1378 posts aimlessly Whirlpool Enthusiast reference: whrl.pl/RdXlZx posted 2014-Apr-26, 11:38 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RdXlZx posted 2014-Apr-26, 11:38 pm AEST benno13 writes... Sounds a bit ridiculous...... Well it feels like it has a sound grounding in psychology either potentially explained with cognitive dissonance or scarcity ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki /Scarcity_%28social_psychology%29 ). If the graduate believes they had beaten a lot of people and that the job is scare they will likely value it higher than they should which may lead to them staying on more than they would've had they thought it wasn't. It's actually directly mentioned in that page I quote, Numerous studies have been conducted on the topic of scarcity in social psychology. One of which sought to examine the effects of scarcity rhetoric in a job advertisement for restaurant server positions. Subjects were presented with two help-wanted ads. One of which suggested numerous job vacancies, while the other suggested that very few were available. The study found that subjects who were presented with the advertisement that suggested limited positions available viewed the company as being a better one to work for than the one that implied many job positions were available. Subjects also felt that the advertisement that suggested limited vacancies translated to higher wages. In short, subjects placed a positive, higher value on the company that suggested that there were scarce job vacancies available.[3] However all the graduate programs I've seen appear to be pretty great. Do not take this comment as an endorsement of what auras818 said I am just saying that their premise does not sound ridiculous at all and actually may work in the company's favor to increase retention [In the nice theoretical framework of psychology, I'm not sure how well it actually works in real life once people who are truly great start getting offers elsewhere]

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Mid-Range
content: User #333236 15276 posts Mid-Range Whirlpool Forums Addict reference: whrl.pl/Rd9XhA posted 2014-Dec-7, 4:14 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rd9XhA posted 2014-Dec-7, 4:14 pm AEST charlimay writes... I was wondering if anyone who has gone through a graduate program... There are various forms of grad "programs" including misnomers. I didn't go thru one myself but have worked closely with those in one. The grads were sent to different operating centres for 6-mth stints to gain an overall understanding of the company operations. There they were given mini-projects of sufficient difficulty to teach but not overwhelm them. After two years depending on available vacancies they were either assigned to a regular position at an op centre or absorbed into the central department at head office. Shouldn't be called a Program if there's no roadmap for their continued employment. If some grads are let go it's due to their poor performance or occasionally part of a companywide downsizing. Although I suspect a number not getting a desired regular position would also start looking elsewhere, but at least with the 2 years training they stand better chance than those without. In my view there's a clear distinction btwn a grad position and one in a grad program. In a large company each dept manager must prepare & be approved by Executives upstairs for an annual budget in advance. They account for thus need to justify cost vs productivity of a grad position, whereas in-program grads are not charged to their dept but to the Program's budget. Dept managers don't answer for in-program grads' productivity, only on how much training they have acquired.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: decapkn89
content: User #702124 32 posts decapkn89 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RewP44 posted 2016-Jan-14, 1:51 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RewP44 posted 2016-Jan-14, 1:51 pm AEST I graduated in 2014 but wasn't particularly concerned with finding a job as I had travel plans and no idea what I wanted in terms of career. So I spent most of 2015 travelling around Australia and abroad, and completed an accounting certificate that gave me austudy income. It's now 2016 (obviously) and the lure of full-time work (or should I say, the lure of the pay) is becoming quite appealing to me. Having said that, I've well and truly missed all the grad programs for this year so I've enrolled into a design diploma at TAFE. Is it worth applying for grad programs when they start advertising them this year and trying to land a job starting in 2017? Or is it too late for me (already 27) and will the fact I'm currently studying at TAFE and doing nothing with my international studies/arts university degree work against me? Alternatively, if I thoroughly enjoy the design diploma, could I apply for grad programs next year, when I am in the final year of my diploma, whilst also applying for design jobs, and then take which ever one is most appealing? Or am I going to be too late? I guess I come from a somewhat laid-back, "alternative" upbringing so I've never felt any pressure to get a degree and get full-time work. Instead I've lived abroad, learnt foreign languages, used public transport and lived off of youth allowance, etc. But now that I am warming to the idea of a career I worry that my "relaxed" history in terms of work and study is going to work against me. I graduated with a really high GPA though I'm now worried it's somewhat useless given it was back in 2014 and I may not be considered eligible for many of the grad programs on offer this year/next year.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Maximo101
content: User #406875 2607 posts Maximo101 Whirlpool Forums Addict reference: whrl.pl/ReRiVp posted 2017-Apr-11, 12:22 pm AEST edited 2017-Apr-11, 12:42 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/ReRiVp posted 2017-Apr-11, 12:22 pm AEST (edited 2017-Apr-11, 12:42 pm AEST) cspr writes... I'm wondering that companies give any salary during the graduate program ? Most seem to be at least 55k base salary plus super, average around 65k base. naypips writes... If one does not get in a grad program, what the alternative? Apply straight for jobs in the industry you studied. May need to apply for entry level jobs and can work up. It is much easier to change roles / positions internally within a company than externally. naypips writes... What do they usually ask during video interviews? Normally they will ask you to tell them about yourself. But this answer should be structured to why you are an ideal candidate for the grad position. They will ask why you want to do the program and what you career goals are. Most likely they will also ask you about the company you applied for and know whether you have researched the company. naypips writes... Can one apply to a graduate program which does not really fit his background, but is in a field he wants to learn and be in? For example, Information Systems degree, Data Science grad program. You can apply to anything, but obviously they are looking to select candidates with a specific knowledge foundation. That's where volunteer / work experience can help. naypips writes... Can you resign from a graduate program? For example you're in the middle of the grad program and you can't proceed for any reason. It is probably specific to each company / grad program. There may be milestones you need to accomplish, some may get you to sign fixed term contracts. The company has invested time and money into you, some may let you resign but you may need to pay back some money / benefits in one way or another.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Maximo101
content: User #406875 2607 posts Maximo101 Whirlpool Forums Addict reference: whrl.pl/ReRiWK posted 2017-Apr-11, 12:29 pm AEST edited 2017-Apr-11, 12:45 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/ReRiWK posted 2017-Apr-11, 12:29 pm AEST (edited 2017-Apr-11, 12:45 pm AEST) orthog. spreading code writes... What's this "old fashioned way"? Please enlighten us. Look for jobs in places specific to your industry. Look on Seek, CareerOne, LinkedIN jobs, browse specific company websites in the Careers sections etc.. Eg: Want to work in finance, go to say Westpacs site in the career section . sigillum_diaboli666 writes... (at age 35), but I've been working for one of the Big-4 banks for over 5 years now (and have about 15 years of other professional work experience). I was considering a Graduate Program (preferably DFAT or something similar). Would my age put me at a disadvantage, or an advantage in your opinion? No age will not put you at a disadvantage. It will actually put you at an advantage since you have lots of other experience with transferable skills. Just remember that all graduate positions are essentially entry level positions with lots of rotations (through various roles) to learn the individual company needs, then they will place you in a specific role at the end. You may need to take a pay cut, since grad positions are paying around 60-65k base which is most likely less than your current employment.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: daddy123
content: User #609789 126 posts daddy123 Participant reference: whrl.pl/ReTxEy posted 2017-May-10, 3:04 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/ReTxEy posted 2017-May-10, 3:04 pm AEST Do you have to be in your final year to apply for a finance graduate program? I've had a very rocky start to uni and needless to say I'm in my second year of attending uni studying first-year subjects (same field different uni.) I don't know why but I'd much rather work and obtain experience than to study for 4 years and then apply; with this in mind how do students go about getting their foot in the door in terms of obtaining experience (ie unpaid work experience or vac work or whatever the term is)

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: Maximo101
content: User #406875 2607 posts Maximo101 Whirlpool Forums Addict reference: whrl.pl/ReTzJx posted 2017-May-11, 11:59 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/ReTzJx posted 2017-May-11, 11:59 am AEST daddy123 writes... Do you have to be in your final year to apply for a finance graduate program? Yes, You need to be in your final year; so have completed your degree by the next year, since graduate programs taking applicants currently are for 2018 stars generally. Alternatively you can still apply for graduate positions generally within 3 years of completing your degree. To get experience you can apply for Summer Internship /vac work type programs but I don't think finance companies may have that sort of thing. So your best bet may just be applying for entry level jobs as casual or part time to get your foot in the door. Eg. bank teller etc..

author: questioner20
content: User #877462 4 posts questioner20 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/Rf9YY2 posted 2020-Oct-15, 9:14 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rf9YY2 posted 2020-Oct-15, 9:14 pm AEST Hi everyone, I am not very familiar with the whole graduate program process and have some questions. I hope this is the right place to ask this. Does anyone know at what stage of the application process that we can be certain that we have an offer and can start thinking about withdrawing from other applications? Some programs have final stages that involve pre-employment checks and a verbal offer. But, is it only once we have signed a contract that everything is certain? Otherwise are we not safe and should we keep going with our other applications too (including their pre-employment checks) and not withdraw from any until we have signed a contract from one place? Thanks.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: HikariGo
content: User #497412 4480 posts HikariGo Whirlpool Forums Addict reference: whrl.pl/Rf9Y3L posted 2020-Oct-15, 9:59 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rf9Y3L posted 2020-Oct-15, 9:59 pm AEST questioner20 writes... Otherwise are we not safe and should we keep going with our other applications too (including their pre-employment checks) and not withdraw from any until we have signed a contract from one place? This is a very contentious issue on here and has ethical considerations. Even if you have a signed contract, you are on probation in graduate programs so it is not like that is a safeguard, although most will not sign anything until the first day on the job anyway. Honestly, with grad programs once any pre-employment checks such as police/referee/baseline clearances are done and you have a verbal offer, I think that you just have to take rely on that, presuming it is your first preference. Obviously, the longer the grad program has been around and its reputation probably play into that as well.

It feels like with pre-employment checks, it's something they do once they already have decided on their candidates?

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: GradTracker
content: User #898042 2 posts GradTracker I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/Rgplrv posted 2022-Mar-15, 9:08 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/Rgplrv posted 2022-Mar-15, 9:08 pm AEST Hey @Hojiyama and @wonderstruck, It would be pretty rare for a big four recruiter to do a in depth background check. The main reason is the sheer number of applications they need to process. Deepest they may go is a police check which would only look into convictions. In terms of checking references, they'll likely only contact references you have on your resume as its convenient. The big take away is most of these graduate recruiters just don't have the time to go that deep. If you're applying for a government agency the background checks will be deeper. Same for the ATO. I wouldn't stress about a bad relationship with a previous employer! Maybe just leave that experience off the resume or take them off as a referee,

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: chompers00
content: User #918193 2 posts chompers00 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgEeyV posted 2023-Oct-8, 3:36 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgEeyV posted 2023-Oct-8, 3:36 pm AEST Hello, not sure sure how many are in the same boat but I have recently finished uni, and have applied to hundreds of business-related grad programs in over the last ten months and to date have not been successful in any of them. This is despite working my arse off in two internships, a volunteer program and a long-standing causal job, as well as repeated careers and mentors sessions to optimise resumes/cover letters. It is becoming incredibly frustrating and disheartening to continually receive the same old rejection emails, especially when you’ve put all the effort you can into snagging an offer. To see so many people on this forum receive offers makes me both happy for them and more angry at my lack of progress at the same time. I was just seeking some form of confirmation that is this a normal part of the process, or is it about who you know, not what you know? Or am I just somehow incredibly unlucky? Sincerely, an increasingly concerned graduate.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: ZeroLithium
content: User #773485 66 posts ZeroLithium Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgEeKM posted 2023-Oct-8, 6:35 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgEeKM posted 2023-Oct-8, 6:35 pm AEST baskinghobo writes... Is there anyway to make the interview process easier so that I don't have to fork out a lot of money for travel if the interview is unsuccessful or is this the only way? It really depends on the employer and the resources they have/are willing to spend on you. For example, some of the bigger grad programs (e.g. Federal government) have been known to fly candidates across the country to attend Assessment centres and/or interviews. Try and negotiate with them and see if you can do your interview over Teams/video/phone interview. I know that in some grad recruitment panels do almost everything online.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: ZeroLithium
content: User #773485 66 posts ZeroLithium Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgEeMx posted 2023-Oct-8, 6:50 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgEeMx posted 2023-Oct-8, 6:50 pm AEST chompers00 writes... I was just seeking some form of confirmation that is this a normal part of the process, or is it about who you know, not what you know? Or am I just somehow incredibly unlucky? This is honestly quite normal and it is extremely disheartening, butt don't let that stop you from applying! There are many things out of your control when it comes to the recruitment process, but there are a few spots where you have control: 1) Your application – the standard these days is the submission of an online form, and your resume. You directly control the content that goes in there, so do your best to put your best foot forward. Put on paper your work experience, your technical experience, and thee things you've learned from them. Some programs will also require you to write a pitch: "why should we pick you over another person" or "what do you bring to the table?" These are generally one pagers that allow you to tailor your skills, experience, and background to the recruitment panel. Do your research on the company, look for what sorts of person/skills they are looking for. Understand what they DO and how you can use your skills to further that. 2) Your interview – if your application succeeds and you get an interview, think about the examples you can give the interviewer. My biggest tip is this: ANSWER THE QUESTION. Use your knowledge gained from researching the position to tailor your answer to the types of things that they might ask. Show a depth of understanding rather than generic answers. Grad programs are fairly lenient in the interviews, and the hardest part is actually getting a spot at the Assessment Centre. Once you get to the AC stage, there are many variables that you can't control so the best you can do is play it by ear; prepare as much as you can but ultimate the AC is there to weed out people with poor social/people skills.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: ZeroLithium
content: User #773485 66 posts ZeroLithium Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgEw8e posted 2023-Oct-20, 6:08 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgEw8e posted 2023-Oct-20, 6:08 pm AEST vegemitefish writes... It's hard to answer the question though... panic ^^; If you are finding it hard to answer questions, my biggest tip would be to simply take like 10 seconds to think and consider what the question is asking before answering. 10 seconds might sound like a long time, but as an interviewer on the panel, we prefer the candidate provide a considered response that covers the various aspects of the question instead of a quick and rushed answer. Many candidates just rush out an incoherent answer, and then having to do a circular answer (where you repeat bits you already said, or your answer went on a tangent before coming back to it). For example, a question might be: "How do you respond to failure? Tell us about a time you failed: what happened, and how did you handle it?" Using the example above, what would your response be? As an exercise, read through the question once, and immediately say your answer out loud to yourself. Then, read it again but this time think for 10 seconds before answering – how has your answer changed? There are multiple parts to this question which you can apply the STAR method to, and you will need to answer all four parts for it to be a full answer. If you take some time to actually consider the question and plan a response, it suddenly becomes much easier to elaborate on your answer.

thread_title: Seriously... whats a graduate program? -  Graduate programs
author: ZeroLithium
content: User #773485 66 posts ZeroLithium Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgLr62 posted 2024-Nov-2, 9:53 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgLr62 posted 2024-Nov-2, 9:53 pm AEST On-going and permanent are the same thing. Chances are they won't kick you out or terminate your employment on a whim, but they have the avenues to do so if warranted. For example, if you severely breach the APS Code of Conduct or commit illegal offences in the duties of your employment – they will have grounds to terminate your employment.

content: User #931694 168 posts helpagradout Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgO9bx posted 2025-Jun-10, 2:27 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgO9bx posted 2025-Jun-10, 2:27 pm AEST I know we'll hear back tomorrow in regards to the next step. Does anyone know if the next step is an interview and if that'd be the last step in the process?

author: IMPERIAL745
content: User #930487 43 posts IMPERIAL745 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgO9cA posted 2025-Jun-10, 2:42 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgO9cA posted 2025-Jun-10, 2:42 pm AEST As far as the job pack goes, yes, the next step is the interview, which is also the final step. After your interview, you will need to provide two references within seven days. Afterwards, everybody who passes to a certain degree will be merit-pooled, and you can choose your preference of team and location, but this is not a guarantee of a job. After all of this, starting late August, they will contact preferred candidates for the positions, and then until October, you will have a chance of receiving a verbal offer for the job.

author: graddd2026
content: User #932789 6 posts graddd2026 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPjBJ posted 2025-Jun-21, 7:48 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPjBJ posted 2025-Jun-21, 7:48 pm AEST Hey Rod_Dog, which stream did you apply for? I was wondering if you had any advice for technical pathway interview?

author: Rod_Dog
content: User #924746 93 posts Rod_Dog Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPkmY posted 2025-Jun-22, 7:28 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPkmY posted 2025-Jun-22, 7:28 pm AEST @keetomato I applied for the Technical Pathway. My AC was a group activity where we had to work together to present some key points/recommendations about a topic to the interviewers, and also answer some questions we were given (from memory). The second part of the AC was an interview with 2(3?) people asking questions that need a STAR format answer (Situation, Task, Action, Result). It was a fair while ago when I did my interview set so things could have changed now, and I believe I saw that they are changing the way they do the hiring process for 2026 cohort, so some things may be different for you. I would just recommend to look at STAR questions online, find/remember a suitable situation from your current or past workplaces, and see how you can adapt that situation to fulfill the STAR method criteria. ChatGPT is really helpful for this (that's what I did). My interview contained 0 technical questions that were related to my degree but again, they said they are changing the hiring process for the 2026 cohort so maybe they will ask this time around, I'm not sure.

author: graddd2026
content: User #932789 6 posts graddd2026 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPlkj posted 2025-Jun-23, 8:37 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPlkj posted 2025-Jun-23, 8:37 pm AEST Thank you for this response!! Seems like there are changes as you mentioned. We have done the AC already and the interview is the next stage. We got comms saying the interview is a mix of motivational, behavioural and some technical questions. But yes will definitely take up your advice on the STAR method :)))

author: grad2421
content: User #933472 19 posts grad2421 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPllA posted 2025-Jun-23, 9:04 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPllA posted 2025-Jun-23, 9:04 pm AEST The Q&A document says that you can only get one offer – how does it work if you applied to multiple streams? Can you only get into the merit pool for a single stream?

author: IMPERIAL745
content: User #930487 43 posts IMPERIAL745 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPlpY posted 2025-Jun-23, 10:51 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPlpY posted 2025-Jun-23, 10:51 pm AEST As far as I remember, in the application it said that you would be considered for all streams, so I think it is just an overall merit pool for everything and you would get offered based on whichever stream fit you the most. For example, if you are doing a mathematics degree, regardless of what they say you are obviously most suited for the mathematics stream and have best chance of getting offer for that instead of the science stream lets say. Edit – you are considered for all except intelligence, intelligence is only if you chose it as your preferred and another thing, if you choose intelligence you are also considered for the rest of the streams.

author: Gradseeker2000
content: User #933705 4 posts Gradseeker2000 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPoRw posted 2025-Jun-27, 6:40 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPoRw posted 2025-Jun-27, 6:40 pm AEST When abouts in February did you start your program? Assuming you started in February.

author: rdabot01
content: User #927149 11 posts rdabot01 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPqRV posted 2025-Jun-30, 11:44 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPqRV posted 2025-Jun-30, 11:44 am AEST Hi Gradseeker2000 (And Rod_Dog ;) ), I'm a 2025 Technical Graduate as well! A lot of the grads, including me, started on 10th Feb. However, we were asked to relocate a week before the start date, although I negotiated to drive down from Sydney 2 days before the start date. They will provide you with the option to stay in temporary accommodation should you require it, with some reasonable allowances provided. The second intake is in early March, which is right about when the Orientation Week happened for us; however, the schedule for next year's graduates may be subject to change.

author: patrick_bateman
content: User #902642 81 posts patrick_bateman Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgN3EV posted 2025-Apr-4, 2:39 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgN3EV posted 2025-Apr-4, 2:39 pm AEST Re BofA insight program, happy to give insight as I did it last year. Emails to notify if you get accepted into insight where sent out on 10 May last year. (Program was on 22 May). Around 30-40 people got selected to attend, and from the insight 10 got offered spots for Summer. Performance during program doesn’t matter imo, but best is to be proactive in the group workshops during insight day and in the Q&A panel seshes. Fairly certain most people who attended the insight program received a 1st round interview. There is a video interview component you have to do which is the next step after insight day – however I don’t think these are scrutinised heavily by the campus recruiter. I butchered mine and still got invited to 1st and then 2nd round interviews. As a tip, the VI from BofA is the exact same as what’s on WSO in their VI guide.

author: jared vennett

author: jared vennett
content: User #932284 43 posts jared vennett Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgN3FL posted 2025-Apr-4, 2:46 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgN3FL posted 2025-Apr-4, 2:46 pm AEST one other q – did you get a call between apps closing and the email or no

author: patrick_bateman
content: User #902642 81 posts patrick_bateman Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgN3PA posted 2025-Apr-4, 5:00 pm AEST edited 2025-Apr-4, 5:06 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgN3PA posted 2025-Apr-4, 5:00 pm AEST (edited 2025-Apr-4, 5:06 pm AEST) Nah only an email. As a rough timeline, from what I recall it was insight day (22 May), VI (30 May), Notified if selected for 1st Round (11 Jun), 1st Round interview (12 Jun) Notified if selected for 2nd Round (14 Jun), 2nd Round interview (17 Jun) —> Offers sent on 22 Jun Would encourage you to reach out to analysts/assocs at BofA for coffee chats/calls. Increases chances greatly and I believe majority of the cohort did that prior to insight apps closing.

Maybe a different process to Sydney?

content: User #926899 44 posts yourmumsyourdad Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPvLd posted 2025-Jul-3, 10:43 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPvLd posted 2025-Jul-3, 10:43 am AEST syd

author: yourmumsyourdad
content: User #926899 44 posts yourmumsyourdad Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPvLG posted 2025-Jul-3, 10:52 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPvLG posted 2025-Jul-3, 10:52 am AEST Reflections on IB recruiting: Each year, investment banking recruitment timelines are moving earlier as firms look to secure top talent well before the traditional "interbank" period. This shift is happening alongside increasing competition for a limited number of high-paying roles. My key advice to students in their earlier years is simple: it is never too early to start preparing and networking. With the rise of institutions like Finma and the growing number of cadetship and early insight programs, the traditional recruitment windows are shrinking. As a result, those relying solely on the old timelines risk falling behind. To stay competitive, it's crucial to start building relationships and developing technical skills well ahead of time. It’s also important to note that the nature of technical interviews is evolving. Questions from guides like the "400 Questions" book are now considered baseline knowledge. Success in interviews increasingly depends on a deeper conceptual understanding rather than rote memorisation. Lastly, don’t let fear or self-consciousness stop you from reaching out to bankers early in your university journey. You might feel it’s “too soon” or “awkward,” but in reality, no one is judging. As long as you're prepared, curious, and respectful of their time, professionals are often more than happy to support you. TLDR: The competition is only getting tougher — start early, build real understanding, and don't be afraid to put yourself out there.

author: calm99
content: User #931938 8 posts calm99 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPvRg posted 2025-Jul-3, 12:09 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPvRg posted 2025-Jul-3, 12:09 pm AEST Not that it matters but what’s the general ranking of banks in terms of reputation and grad/intern training programs? GS/UBS/Maccap I believe are top three but what about the other BBs and boutiques in Australia?

author: yourmumsyourdad
content: User #926899 44 posts yourmumsyourdad Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPvR1 posted 2025-Jul-3, 12:22 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPvR1 posted 2025-Jul-3, 12:22 pm AEST Hello calm99 happy to go ahead and answer this Yes you are right. In Australia GS, UBS and Macap are regarded as the best and most lucrative internships. The other key bulge bracket banks that operate in Aus are Morgan Stanley, JPM (who are rising as a ket player in AUS) and BOFA. There is also a local bank called Barrenjoey who have performed well since their inception a few years ago and is also a lucrative internship in Australia. Other bulge bracket banks who are well known in the US are Citi and Detschue Bank, however, they are not as lucratuve when it comes to the internship process. There are numerous boutiques in AUS. Key players include -> Stanton road, Gresham partners, Grant Samuel,Record Point, Lazard, Flagstaff etc. These are also lucractive and high paying. However, obviosuly not as well known and 'prestigious' as your top 3 BB.

content: User #932425 12 posts theaspiringbanker I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPv1a posted 2025-Jul-3, 2:15 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPv1a posted 2025-Jul-3, 2:15 pm AEST How much networking did you guys do? Is it more the US way to recruit?

author: yourmumsyourdad
content: User #926899 44 posts yourmumsyourdad Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPv1r posted 2025-Jul-3, 2:19 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPv1r posted 2025-Jul-3, 2:19 pm AEST NO! Actually somewhat to the contrary. Comp for GS Grad (which is argugably the best internship) actually recieve lower comp than competitors such as UBS and BOFA. Additionally, boutiques often pay more than BB. On your point re prestige, it is only imporant to the extent you care about PE exisits. Although, often you get more responsibility at boutiques PE firms often prefer those from BB. Here 'prestige' does play a role.

author: yourmumsyourdad
content: User #926899 44 posts yourmumsyourdad Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPM1t posted 2025-Jul-21, 10:51 pm AEST edited 2025-Jul-21, 10:56 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPM1t posted 2025-Jul-21, 10:51 pm AEST (edited 2025-Jul-21, 10:56 pm AEST) I’ve previously shared the view on this forum that UBS, GS, and Macquarie are the top investment banking internships in Australia. However, I’ve since re-evaluated my perspective, particularly after observing recent deal activity and considering long-term career development. In my view, JPMorgan now deserves a place above Macquarie when assessing internships from a career perspective for Australian students. As highlighted in a recent AFR article, JPMorgan has advised on some of the largest and most strategic transactions in the market, including the Santos and ADNOC deal. When you combine this with JPM’s unmatched global presence and strong reputation in the US, the long-term mobility and international exposure it offers arguably outweigh Macquarie’s strong domestic footprint. While some might argue that names like BofA or Morgan Stanley should rank higher based on their global standing, I think it’s important to weigh that against their presence and deal activity in Australia. On that front, they tend to sit outside the top tier. So if I were building an IB "starting five" based on the Australian market, I’d say the Big 4 are clear: 1. Goldman Sachs (LeBron James) – the undisputed GOAT, combining elite global execution with prestige and consistency 2. UBS (Nikola Jokić) – technically elite, unassuming but incredibly effective, and always involved in major plays with huge impact 3. JPMorgan (Jayson Tatum) – rising fast, with global range and increasing leadership in local transactions 4. Macquarie (Patty Mills) – the Aussie veteran, proven performer in its home court with strong institutional trust The rest are still on the bench, waiting for more minutes. Open to thoughts , curious to hear how others would rank their top picks. FYI this is just for a bit of fun, all internships are good!

content: User #932010 118 posts ib_offer_pls Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPW6H posted 2025-Jul-30, 2:21 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPW6H posted 2025-Jul-30, 2:21 pm AEST Does interbank start today? @Grad_123456 – I think interbank will start next week, I know some firms mentioned calls will start going out from Tuesday next week (5th August). Hi, just had a question. What is the interbank period? And haven't most investment banks finished their interviews for summer internship? Thanks. @zinup – my understanding, happy to be corrected, interbank is basically an agreement amongst banks to hire summer interns and conduct interviews from Interbank day. I think this is an agreement held by most BB IBs. You are correct in saying a lot of the boutique investment banks have already completed recruiting for summer internships. Has anyone received email for psychometrics for Grant Samuel Syd? @gabber – I am pretty sure Grant Samuel has finished recruiting, based on this forum. Could be wrong. Not sure if they have psychometrics as part of their process, most of the boutiques usually don't.

author: yourmumsyourdad
content: User #926899 44 posts yourmumsyourdad Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP0BT posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:20 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP0BT posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:20 pm AEST Moelis Financial (MA) offers are out via phone. heard from a mate. This for their usual generalist IB internship. My mates stats (which he has agreed to share): GO8 uni Commerce degree 77 WAM 1 boutique advisory internships 1 fund manager internship 2 coffee chats at MA prior to ints. P.S. Good luck to everyone for interbank next week. All your preparation will come in handy. Make sure to stay relaxed and confident in your interviews.

author: yourmumsyourdad
content: User #926899 44 posts yourmumsyourdad Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP0Ca posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:31 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP0Ca posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:31 pm AEST Also a quick update on markets internships, BofA won’t be taking on a summer intern in markets this year as there’s no current business need. To be honest, I’m not entirely sure about the long-term viability of going into markets straight after undergrad. If I were seriously considering it, I’d either go all-in and try to break into quant, where the compensation is strong early on, or opt for IB, which offers far better exit opportunities. From my perspective, markets roles seem incredibly competitive for jobs that don’t really lead to many exits. I could be completely off here, so happy to be challenged if others see it differently.

author: TheLimitExists
content: User #518413 41 posts TheLimitExists Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOqrA posted 2025-Apr-29, 5:54 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOqrA posted 2025-Apr-29, 5:54 pm AEST Was it a timed assessment, i.e., will the meeting room close at a certain time and you must submit whatever work you have completed?

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: aidenh37
content: User #637085 721 posts aidenh37 Whirlpool Enthusiast reference: whrl.pl/RgOqI0 posted 2025-Apr-29, 11:22 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOqI0 posted 2025-Apr-29, 11:22 pm AEST Super relaxed. I did have my camera on initially to present myself professionally, but then while performing each assessment I had myself muted and camera off, no issues. Each assessment is 40 minutes, 45 to be safe and allow for introduction to the task etc. Both tasks (Digital and Generalist) were written tasks. The meeting room does not automatically close, you are simply expected to stop work once the time limit expires and upload it to the candidate portal. It's all very straightforward and not too dissimilar from a supervised assessment at uni. Definitely had fun with this one once I got in!

author: Skewness
content: User #932864 11 posts Skewness I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOIZy posted 2025-May-16, 11:57 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOIZy posted 2025-May-16, 11:57 am AEST Hi all, Looks like I was unsuccessful for the data stream, unless more AC emails are coming out. Does anyone who was successful have any advice about the written assessment that you felt contributed to your success? I already try to apply the STAR method, although I’m sure I could strengthen that skill with some practice. Also, those who were successful, what’s your level of experience/education in data science? I’m wondering if I need to pivot towards applying for Digital streams, as my degree was only partially focussed on data/statistics, and my data science work experience is somewhat limited.

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: sss244
content: User #932224 47 posts sss244 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOI44 posted 2025-May-16, 1:19 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOI44 posted 2025-May-16, 1:19 pm AEST O.P. Don't count yourself out too soon, they will be sending actual rejections for everyone not progressing. When it comes to online assessment, written assessment, video interviews, etc I have a notebook with situations/scenarios, strengths, technical skill, and some other things that are commonly asked. So when it comes to things like this, where it is timed, I can give a well rounded answer without spending too much time thinking/planning. As for experience/education I have a BA in Comp Sci, a partial MA in Data, and no experience.

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: financewolf
content: User #927506 147 posts financewolf Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOWMa posted 2025-May-28, 3:08 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOWMa posted 2025-May-28, 3:08 pm AEST emkroseh writes... Does the interview go for the entire timeframe (roughly two hours)? Or can I expect to be finished beforehand? Only asking as I have an elderly pet who needs attention every two hours or so as they are end of life :(. just want to plan accordingly The structure for me was 11:05 start, 11:15-11:45 group assessment, then break with cameras off till 12:00, then individual interview from 12:10 to 12:40-50, then questions as a whole group 12:50-1pm. Can't say for sure your interview will be the same but might be better to organise someone else to care for your pet, hope all goes well!
