thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: emkroseh
content: User #932804 11 posts emkroseh I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOYHl posted 2025-May-30, 10:38 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOYHl posted 2025-May-30, 10:38 am AEST I completed mine a couple of days ago. The interviewers are really nice and understanding! I was a bit flustered with one question and had to think for a good while and they genuinely don't mind. They will ask questions on top of your answer to their original question. I think you want to keep STAR answers concise anyway, but my entire one on one lasted roughly 20 minutes or less.

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: mEp3ii2
content: User #933597 5 posts mEp3ii2 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOY0b posted 2025-May-30, 3:38 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOY0b posted 2025-May-30, 3:38 pm AEST This is the email Thank you for your application and continued interest in the Australian Government Graduate Program – Digital Stream. Unfortunately, on this occasion you have not been successful in progressing to the next stage of the recruitment process. We received a high number of applications, and the standard was incredibly strong, therefore progressing to the next stage was particularly competitive. Due to the volume of applications received, we cannot offer individual feedback. While you were not selected to continue, we want to thank you for the effort you put into your application and wish you all the best in your future endeavours. If you are still interested, and in a position to do so, we encourage you to apply again next year.

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: aidenh37
content: User #637085 721 posts aidenh37 Whirlpool Enthusiast reference: whrl.pl/RgOY7x posted 2025-May-30, 5:56 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOY7x posted 2025-May-30, 5:56 pm AEST user235292 writes... A mistake because the AI checking the work would give less points for work done by humans working against the clock. I have a hard time believing HR is reading hundreds of written assessments. Well one way or another clearly my non-AI generated work made the cut, because I was invited to the AC. I'd be very surprised if they weren't reading the majority, as they have a recruitment contractor to help and they put it in the assessment that AI should not be used. This tells me that anyone with *too much* content, didn't make the cut, as having too much content at a high standard is a great indicator of AI usage. After all, nobody is perfect, and the time limit is designed to challenge the candidate while still being enjoyable. Another example which I'm yet to find out if it's a success or not, is the AGGP STEM stream written assessment. In this assessment, I was able to submit a quality response but only completed 2 out of the 4 parts. I'm betting this is not going to be an issue to any reasonable person. Depends on what they're after.

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: emkroseh
content: User #932804 11 posts emkroseh I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP3dK posted 2025-Aug-5, 3:42 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP3dK posted 2025-Aug-5, 3:42 pm AEST Hey all. I got a rejection for the data stream (which I was wildly unqualified for so I’m not surprised haha). Here is how the email roughly reads for those who want to know: Thank you for attending the assessment centre for … grad program. Over 1000 candidates were invited to the assessment centre, which has resulted in a highly competitive selection pool across each stream. Regrettably, we wish to inform you that your application has been unsuccessful on this occasion. Should you wish to receive feedback, contact us by X date via @their email. Thanks for your interest and time taken.. etc etc. We encourage you to keep an eye on (some website) for other roles that may interest you. We wish you the very best in your future career opportunities. Wasn’t word for word, but you get the idea. Congrats to all those who made it to the merit pool and possible future job offers!

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: Researcher
content: User #933121 52 posts Researcher Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP3Xr posted 2025-Aug-6, 11:54 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP3Xr posted 2025-Aug-6, 11:54 am AEST I would think that most graduate programs especially in public service /gov are highly competitive. Even after being placed in the merit pool- because services Australia requires their graduates to do a three month service delivery, some decline their offer as other grad roles don’t do this or for other reasons such as relocations, hence accepting another offer in another APS down the line. So maybe more chance for merit pool candidates in services Australia to get a VO. Of course this is just my understanding. I’ve read previous forums from the past couple years for services Australia and don’t see that many people get VO unfortunately. But of course every year is different. There may be more openings this year compared to last. Who knows.

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: Ashen_Chevalier
content: User #913332 279 posts Ashen_Chevalier Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgP3Zp posted 2025-Aug-6, 12:24 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP3Zp posted 2025-Aug-6, 12:24 pm AEST The Services Australia program seems to be really good though. The service delivery stuff is only 3 months and the program is 10 months in total. When you complete the program, you get promoted to an APS5 classification.

thread_title: 2026 Services Australia National Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: Grad24
content: User #923844 12 posts Grad24 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP4xA posted 2025-Aug-6, 9:12 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP4xA posted 2025-Aug-6, 9:12 pm AEST Current grad here. I would say the service delivery was definitely the highlight and really fun. It’s not just taking calls all day. We do lots of team bonding activities, getting to know the organisation and learn about the services we provide, shadow how frontline staffs do their work etc. Grads at the same base location share the same office space so we all hang out a lot. You definitely won’t be lonely if you moved interstate.

author: oatcap123
content: User #932837 14 posts oatcap123 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPWkM posted 2025-Jul-29, 5:22 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPWkM posted 2025-Jul-29, 5:22 pm AEST @Track36483 Thank you for taking the time to attend the assessment centre for ASIC's 2026 Graduate Program. In this instance, we unfortunately cannot extend you an offer. However, we were impressed by your skills, experience, and the strong performance you demonstrated during the process. Based on the panel's recommendation, you have been rated as suitable and placed into our merit pool. This means that over the next 12 months, we may contact you to discuss your ongoing interest in the program. We may also reach out to you if other roles become available across ASIC which match your skills, experience and qualifications. In the meantime, should you have any questions, please don’t hesitate to contact us at emergingtalent@asic.gov.au to arrange a discussion. Thank you once again for your interest in the role and for sharing your expertise with us, and we hope to be in touch soon. Kind Regards, ASIC Emerging Talent Team

content: User #932258 31 posts heygrad1010 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOmKg posted 2025-Apr-25, 3:07 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOmKg posted 2025-Apr-25, 3:07 pm AEST @toekneeabbutt hey!! what stream did you apply for! do you like it so far? and hows the online assessment? i have to do it for the IT stream but not sure if it includes coding... thanks!!

author: rephrasing
content: User #932587 171 posts rephrasing Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOmNn posted 2025-Apr-25, 3:50 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOmNn posted 2025-Apr-25, 3:50 pm AEST heygrad1010 writes... hows the online assessment? Just did the IT Stream one. 9 Questions Total 1 Voice recording (Max 3 mins) 1 Code analysis (Very very simple function in Python) 2 MC 1 Architecture explanation (Requires document download) Don’t want to spoil too much, but just a bit of what to expect. Took me an full hour (Depends how much detail you want to go into on questions IG) Good luck :)

author: bigloggy
content: User #932286 90 posts bigloggy Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOm6G posted 2025-Apr-25, 8:38 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOm6G posted 2025-Apr-25, 8:38 pm AEST Just submitted the Marketing & Comms stream application. It was straightforward, had an audio component (no video) but mainly text-based questions. Good luck everybody!

author: lalaland11
content: User #927124 27 posts lalaland11 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOoCR posted 2025-Apr-27, 7:15 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOoCR posted 2025-Apr-27, 7:15 pm AEST Hi everyone, I’m not sure how to prepare for the assessment. Has anyone applied for the design role and completed it? I’m feeling a bit lost. Any advice would be appreciated! :)

author: rafadazza
content: User #931898 73 posts rafadazza Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOoXy posted 2025-Apr-28, 8:22 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOoXy posted 2025-Apr-28, 8:22 am AEST @lalaland11 Yeah I’ve completed the design assessment. It’s pretty straight forward if you know the design process particularly accessibility and understanding how to proceed with research. There’s a question that’ll give you features and how you can iterate on the design to meet accessibility needs and UX needs, another where you respond to an email with a client prompt with questions to understand their issue and another with a results chart from user testing where you give your report on the findings. Personally, think it’s miles better than doing a psychometric test that has barely any bearing on design work. Good luck!

content: User #913332 279 posts Ashen_Chevalier Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgOviR posted 2025-May-2, 4:34 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOviR posted 2025-May-2, 4:34 pm AEST Sweet. Hoping to at least make it to the AC this time. I think I did fairly well with the assessment questions.

author: toekneeabbutt
content: User #927025 17 posts toekneeabbutt I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOvkC posted 2025-May-2, 5:08 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOvkC posted 2025-May-2, 5:08 pm AEST @heygrad1010 I applied for the Tax stream in Adelaide. Honestly, the work is a lot better than I expected. The work culture is super chill and the pay is surpringsly good for a grad role. My online assessment last year was a one on one panel interview with 4 people on the panel. They asked 4-5 behavioral questions and we were given material one hour before the interview to prepare a presentation. After that, if you did well you would get placed in a merit pool and then its more of a luck game. From what a remember, there were more than 700 people in the merit pool and around 350ish got offers. But that was because last years budget was a lot smaller than previous years. But best of luck to everyone :)

author: Ashen_Chevalier
content: User #913332 279 posts Ashen_Chevalier Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgOGpI posted 2025-May-13, 6:53 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOGpI posted 2025-May-13, 6:53 pm AEST Just got an email which says: We would like to provide you with some clarity around how the site selection in our Graduate application process will be used. In our recruitment process candidates will only be assessed based on the site they have selected to work in. Any additional site/s you may have selected as a secondary relocation option do not form part of the assessment process, and you will only be assessed for your preferred location. Regards, ATO Careers

content: User #933375 12 posts product-design I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOOwH posted 2025-May-22, 8:14 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOOwH posted 2025-May-22, 8:14 am AEST I (Design Stream) got my invitation for assessment centre in June, but it’ll be my first one ever, does anyone know what could be expected? 1. author: PinguFan01@
content: User #932708 4 posts PinguFan01@ I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOPGE posted 2025-May-23, 10:07 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOPGE posted 2025-May-23, 10:07 am AEST Hi there, Just had my interview for taxation today. For the sake of fairness of people who have already interviewed and those preparing hard, I won't detail the scenario. But the 1 hour preparation time you receive is more than enough for what the task entails. The remainder of the interview comprises of behavioural questions which you can easily prepare for by looking at reviews on Glassdoor or Prosple or just general interview website pages. Best of luck, you'll smash it!

author: JustMe521
content: User #933238 7 posts JustMe521 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOPH9 posted 2025-May-23, 10:35 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOPH9 posted 2025-May-23, 10:35 am AEST How did you feel you went @PinguFan01

author: PinguFan01@
content: User #932708 4 posts PinguFan01@ I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOPIY posted 2025-May-23, 10:47 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOPIY posted 2025-May-23, 10:47 am AEST @Justme521 Thanks for asking :). Like any interview I have, there were things I think I did well and answers I definitely could have improved. I would say there was maybe one curveball in that some of my behavioural questions seemed to double up a little so that was a bit difficult to respond to. But overall I'd say it went fairly ok. The people who interviewed me were lovely so I definitely wouldn't be nervous about that aspect of it. Good luck if you have an interview coming up in the next few days/weeks!!

The email doesn't say much. to make it fair considering some have done it now without any prior knowledge. i doubt anyone will give specifics. i can say that they give you the materials 1 hour before your interview, so make sure you’re free. that one hour is more than enough time to do the small 5 min presentation

author: Pineapple1202
content: User #795157 44 posts Pineapple1202 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOWRR posted 2025-May-28, 4:30 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOWRR posted 2025-May-28, 4:30 pm AEST I’m more nervous about the behavioural questions than the presentation lol. For anyone that’s already completed the interview, how difficult would you say it was overall?

author: Kaiser123
content: User #901938 8 posts Kaiser123 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOW1z posted 2025-May-28, 6:45 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOW1z posted 2025-May-28, 6:45 pm AEST The questions are on the relative simple side (5.5/10 difficulty) as you would expect from a grad position, they are not able to ask technical questions (except maybe the IT stream). I would suggest you to practice a short introduction about yourself question and question relating to what skills/experience you can bring to the grad role based on the skills listed in the advertisement (work experience, uni clubs, degree field, volunteer experience, self learning modules you did) – not just vague but actually practice speaking exactly why you are essentially a better candidate to be hired than others who have applied and sell yourself. In addition to the 2 questions above to practice some generic behaviour questions you can search online and relate it to the questions asked by the interviewer Based on pre-work.

author: 9bornot9b
content: User #933560 8 posts 9bornot9b I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOXfn posted 2025-May-28, 9:41 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOXfn posted 2025-May-28, 9:41 pm AEST Did mine last week. The presentation is quite easy and nothing to be concerned about although I'd definitely give yourself time to complete it. The behavioral questions were slightly harder than last time but still not anything insane. My personal main problem is that I rambled an absolute ton due to nerves so I missed crucial things I originally intended to say, especially on what I can bring to the role :\ Interviewers are a delight as always though, incredibly friendly and there's zero additional pressure from their presence.

author: financewolf
content: User #927506 147 posts financewolf Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOY35 posted 2025-May-30, 4:49 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOY35 posted 2025-May-30, 4:49 pm AEST user235292 writes... author: Velaris
content: User #931368 8 posts Velaris I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOY7P posted 2025-May-30, 5:59 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOY7P posted 2025-May-30, 5:59 pm AEST I just had my interview and honestly, it wasn’t as scary as I thought it’d be! :’) The presentation was super straightforward just had to talk for 5 to 7 minutes, no slides or anything. After that, they asked one general question and four behavioural ones, and then followed up a bit more on two of them. The panel had two people and they are actually really sweet and made the whole vibe super chill. They explained everything clearly at the start and made me feel really comfortable, so it didn’t feel too formal or intense at all. Best of luck to whoever has their interview left. :)

author: remy1
content: User #933263 4 posts remy1 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgO1Jf posted 2025-Jun-2, 4:28 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgO1Jf posted 2025-Jun-2, 4:28 pm AEST Just had my interview (Tax stream). Was one HR person and one Graduate on the call. It was super chill, the presentation is similar to written assignments/ group tasks in other APS graduate program applications. Then there was one motivational question and three behavioural questions. All very standard questions. They asked a few follow-ups, but they were just clarifications; there were no curveballs. The whole thing lasted about half an hour and was definitely the most chill interview I've had so far.

author: Ashen_Chevalier
content: User #913332 279 posts Ashen_Chevalier Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPXgX posted 2025-Jul-30, 5:02 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPXgX posted 2025-Jul-30, 5:02 pm AEST Got this email: In our initial timeline of the recruitment process for the 2026 ATO Graduate Program we advised candidates that interview outcomes would be issued by late July. This year we have had an unprecedented number of applicants and you have all been very competitive. As such, it is taking slightly longer than anticipated to finalise the merit pool. We wish to advise that we will begin updating candidates of their outcomes next week in early August and apologise for the delay. We thank you for your patience and understanding and hope you remain eager to join the 2026 ATO Graduate Program. Kind regards, Entry Level Programs

You might have 50 people in a merit pool for an office, those people’s details are given to internal managers etc and they chose which, say 30 people to hire

author: chijc003
content: User #934840 8 posts chijc003 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP591 posted 2025-Aug-8, 1:05 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP591 posted 2025-Aug-8, 1:05 pm AEST yeah the process you’ve said is absolutely correct, but they do a big cut from interviews to merit pool, so obviously not guaranteed post merit pool but it’s higher than 50/50 (depending on availability of course) but the intent is for it to be higher than 50/50

author: waitingsucks
content: User #935110 2 posts waitingsucks I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP6ai posted 2025-Aug-8, 1:09 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6ai posted 2025-Aug-8, 1:09 pm AEST As per the ATO, referring to successful Assessment Centre outcomes: "We'll add suitable graduates to a merit pool. The merit pool is not ranked. We'll use the merit pool to fill positions in the program." This suggests to me that all merit pool entrants are guaranteed a role, as there is no ranking system in place.

author: Ashen_Chevalier
content: User #913332 279 posts Ashen_Chevalier Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgP6ar posted 2025-Aug-8, 1:12 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6ar posted 2025-Aug-8, 1:12 pm AEST The merit pool does NOT guarantee a role. It's entirely possible that people might be picked over you, even if you're suitable for a particular role.

author: product-design
content: User #933375 12 posts product-design I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP9qw posted 2025-Aug-12, 11:36 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP9qw posted 2025-Aug-12, 11:36 am AEST But I saw 1 person from Marketing & Comms, and another from Design Stream both get a ref check email. My hypothesis is that that typically for big graduate programs like this, they split up the workload between different hiring managers. Each hiring manager has varying workloads, so emails may be sent in batches without seemingly any logical order, more so based on when your batch is completed. I'm still waiting on Design Stream email, so finger crossed it is today

author: user482762
content: User #926510 2 posts user482762 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP9xz posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:10 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP9xz posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:10 pm AEST +1 ref check – Gosford – Taxation (received yesterday). Anyone else from Gosford? Seems like they are having a hard time deciding who they want to put in the merit pool, likely because of competitive interviews this year or hiring constraints? which means they are really trying to raise the bar for a final shortlist and double check numbers/candidates suitability. Last year almost everyone who was merit pooled followed up on last years thread saying they received an offer. After the interviews last year they sent out either rejection or merit pool emails pretty much at the same time. My interview this year was so much better than last year, and I still felt it would be unlikely I got a merit pool this time around considering all this messaging. Interviewed for AGGP as well – probably my best interview ever and still received a rejection. Tough year

content: User #928251 70 posts staticdesign Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP9zH posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:44 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP9zH posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:44 pm AEST I think everyone whose referee speaks favourably about them will proceed to the Merit Pool — I guess it's a way for the ATO to cull some more applicants before finalising the pool.

author: changi22
content: User #926200 8 posts changi22 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP9z9 posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:53 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP9z9 posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:53 pm AEST I'm currently working at the ATO and was previously a grad: the hiring budget for grads across streams/locations is a lot smaller than in previous cohorts. The intakes in 2023 and 2024 were quite large, and they had both a mid-year intake and a normal intake. In 2025 however, the grad cohort was significantly smaller and with just 1 intake. I've heard from reliable sources that the grad intake for 2026 is going to be even smaller than 2025. All this to say – keep your expectations low and continue applying for other roles and other programs. Its a tough hiring year but there will definitely be something good around the corner for all of you, it just might not be at the ATO.

author: user482762
content: User #926510 2 posts user482762 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP9Ay posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:57 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP9Ay posted 2025-Aug-12, 1:57 pm AEST I hope so. But it’s different to last year, they’re doing it before merit pool offers which seems like they are looking to reduce/revise the list somehow. Some people may have offers elsewhere or are no longer available, especially with the delay… a few top candidates might have secured positions elsewhere. I’d hope the reference calls are just to check APS suitability and consistency with the interview/application. Assuming you didn’t lie/over exaggerate skills at any stage of your application and your references endorse you well you should still be suitable after a reference check – getting to this stage already means they liked your interview/application. Lots of APS grad interviews have a 20-50% success rate from what I’ve heard, they’ve already heavily shortlisted candidates at the interview stage… I’d say making it to a reference check stage like this pushes those odds up to 50-80% (assuming they give out rejections as well). But I also can’t be certain why they’re doing this, so I’m not entirely sure :/

thread_title: NAB Starcamp 2025 September & November -  Graduate programs
author: Murkuri
content: User #934245 10 posts Murkuri I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPwn9 posted 2025-Jul-3, 7:58 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPwn9 posted 2025-Jul-3, 7:58 pm AEST Oh I forgot to say I got the call. The interview was mostly behavioral as in 'tell me about yourself', 'if you were trying to explain something technical to a non technical person how would you go about it', 'If you are learning something new how would you approach it'. There was some specific questions like which intake you wish to undertake, are you available to work on premises, your working rights etc. The phone interview was only 15mins. They said that next weeks interview is more comprehensive (45mins) where you they ask more questions about you and also ask you to demonstrate your understanding through a recent project (I'm kinda cooked on this aspect).

thread_title: NAB Starcamp 2025 September & November -  Graduate programs
author: tokkitokki
content: User #931371 15 posts tokkitokki I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPGO3 posted 2025-Jul-14, 11:55 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPGO3 posted 2025-Jul-14, 11:55 pm AEST yeah I did! My project wasn't super impressive but imo i think at this level they're mostly just seeing how well you can communicate. I didn't get any feedback so I'm not sure if I did well. They did ask me some follow up questions so be prepared to explain your decisions. Overall the process was good! I have no complaints at all even if I don't get an offer. They were really clear about the process from the start and supportive for the whole interview

thread_title: NAB Starcamp 2025 September & November -  Graduate programs
author: rephrasing
content: User #932587 171 posts rephrasing Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgQaHG posted 2025-Aug-13, 4:25 pm AEST edited 2025-Aug-13, 4:32 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgQaHG posted 2025-Aug-13, 4:25 pm AEST (edited 2025-Aug-13, 4:32 pm AEST) +1 Rejection (And same comments as above, felt well, was well…. Ah well) FYI, the email. Thank you once again for applying for NAB StarCamp and taking time to meet with our team. Thank you also for your patience as we worked through our decision making process. We appreciate your interest and the effort you put into your application and assessments. After careful consideration, we regret to inform you that we have decided to move forward with other candidates at this time. This was decision was difficult as we had many strong candidates and limited places on the program. We understand that emails like this can be disheartening, but we don’t want them to be! It can take some time to find an opportunity that you love and is right for you. Although we are not proceeding with your application at this time, we hope your experience with us was valuable in your career development. Thank you for taking the time to apply for our program. We would love to stay in touch to keep you updated on any upcoming programs as we would encourage you to reapply in the future. To stay updated, you can follow the official NAB LinkedIn page and follow our hashtag #NABTechCareers and #NABStarCamp for more information on our early talent programs. You can also visit the early careers page at nab.com.au. We wish you the best of luck in your job search and we hope to see your application again in the future.

The Department of Justice uses recruitment pools to build a bank of talent for future opportunities. Applicants found suitable in this pool, may be considered for subsequent, similar vacancies, with the Department of Justice for the duration of the pool. ” Source: https://search.jobs.wa.gov.au /page.php?pageID=160&windowUID=0&AdvertID=375610

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPHFZ posted 2025-Jul-15, 7:48 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPHFZ posted 2025-Jul-15, 7:48 pm AEST I'm a procrastinating lawyer who went through the Sydney process a few years ago, so I can't guarantee this is still the case or that it's even accurate to begin with. But back then, people generally understood that G+T supposedly used AI to scan our cover letters and other materials for key words to progress candidates for psychometric testing. With ChatGPT and other advancements now, I’d imagine things have evolved quite a bit since then! Hope this helps. :)

author: bootyman123
content: User #933271 16 posts bootyman123 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPHHT posted 2025-Jul-15, 8:25 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPHHT posted 2025-Jul-15, 8:25 pm AEST I got no confirmation from Ashurst either, so I think it's normal. If the other firms who use cappfinity are anything to go by, we should be emailed a report soon.

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPHJD posted 2025-Jul-15, 9:03 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPHJD posted 2025-Jul-15, 9:03 pm AEST Yeah totally, without fail there were always G+T paralegals who didn't make it through every single year when I was still in uni. That said, the whole process for all the firms can be pretty arbitrary and can be incredibly non-sensical and unfair at times (as I keep reminding my friend who is going through the process this year who reminded me about Whirlpool after all this time). While there might be general rules of thumb, there are always going to be exceptions to the rule, so you just have to try not to drive yourself too crazy reading into it all too much and just know none of it is a genuine reflection on your self-worth or whether you will succeed in commercial law. :)

content: User #932851 15 posts malfoy I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPMHC posted 2025-Jul-21, 4:41 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMHC posted 2025-Jul-21, 4:41 pm AEST Fortunately (unfortunately) can't relate to that problem^

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPMId posted 2025-Jul-21, 4:52 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMId posted 2025-Jul-21, 4:52 pm AEST This is completely normal, it can even reflect positively showing that you’re in demand! Take this with a grain of salt as it's just my two cents but it's common for people to RSVP “yes” to multiple events and attend portions of each. In the meantime, it’s a good idea to reach out to the organisers and ask whether recordings will be available for any parts you might miss due to other information sessions scheduled that evening. You don’t need to mention which firms, as that’s honestly none of their business, but do clarify that the conflict is due to overlapping information nights, so they don’t mistakenly assume it’s a work/uni-related absence.

author: Sprayandpray
content: User #934578 23 posts Sprayandpray I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPMJv posted 2025-Jul-21, 5:15 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMJv posted 2025-Jul-21, 5:15 pm AEST Thanks all for the response, really helpful and grateful for the advice!

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPMLi posted 2025-Jul-21, 5:48 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMLi posted 2025-Jul-21, 5:48 pm AEST My general two cents – while informal sessions like coffee catchups or information sessions aren’t formally assessed in the same way as interviews, it’s still important to approach every part of the process with care and professionalism. Things like being responsive over email, showing reasonable availability (we don’t expect you to clear your schedules by any means but it doesn’t leave a great impression when candidates say their only availability in the next three weeks is 31 July 2025 5:55pm to 6:10pm), and being present and engaged during interactions does make a difference. While these informal touchpoints typically aren’t deal-breakers on their own, they do form part of the broader impression we provide back to the recruitment team. We’re generally asked to report back on things like attitude, preparedness, and overall enthusiasm. Turning up late to a one-on-one catchup, asking silly questions that could have been Googled beforehand at an information evening, or drinking too much at a networking event and calling a partner a corporate square (just why?!) is going to leave a negative impression, especially when compared to candidates who are making the effort. That said, life happens, and extenuating circumstances are absolutely understood. For example, I knew someone who had to miss a few sessions after getting their wisdom teeth removed – HR across multiple firms made it abundantly clear they didn’t want them showing up fresh out of surgery. Firms also know that you’ll have competing events – it’s about the overall effort and attitude. So if something comes up, don’t stress, just make sure to communicate clearly and proactively. The main thing is that under no circumstances should you fail to follow up after committing to attend or ghost them hoping it'll go unnoticed. It not only comes across as disrespectful to those who’ve set aside time for you, it gives the impression that you’re unreliable or do not follow through on your word (which is at the end of the day, all we've really got).

author: Megabunda
content: User #934579 4 posts Megabunda I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPMLj posted 2025-Jul-21, 5:48 pm AEST edited 2025-Jul-21, 6:46 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMLj posted 2025-Jul-21, 5:48 pm AEST (edited 2025-Jul-21, 6:46 pm AEST) Deleted

author: overthinker123

author: overthinker123
content: User #889088 45 posts overthinker123 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPM3B posted 2025-Jul-22, 1:02 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPM3B posted 2025-Jul-22, 1:02 am AEST surprising ngl there is a certain type they hire and grades are def a major factor

author: Sprayandpray
content: User #934578 23 posts Sprayandpray I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPM8B posted 2025-Jul-22, 8:41 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPM8B posted 2025-Jul-22, 8:41 am AEST There’s probably a lot more that go into it than grades. I’m definitely not an expert in recruitment but was lucky enough to progress despite weaker grades. It probably depends on how you portrayed your t6 experience – did you take on “substantive” responsibilities in a “substantive” team (used very loosely). E.g., perhaps a paralegal role in the DR team may have given you more exposure to drafting/research than an intern role in one of the technology teams – not saying you don’t learn much in these teams, I’m sure you did and you will, but you’d likely do more research or drafting in the DR team (again, comes down to how you portray your experience). I’ve also been told other factors may include your ECs (did you have leadership positions or do comps) and whether you demonstrated a genuine interest in the application, sometimes saying “I’m really interested in X” isn’t enough, you’d probably have to mention an ongoing case the firm’s taking, who the partner taking the lead is and why that case is interesting to you. - Just my two cents, probably doesn’t mean much but hope it helps you get a peace of mind. I also don’t think the “oh that firm only hires a certain type” is a good mentality to have. I’m sure most don’t.

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPNfB posted 2025-Jul-22, 10:37 am AEST edited 2025-Jul-22, 10:47 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNfB posted 2025-Jul-22, 10:37 am AEST (edited 2025-Jul-22, 10:47 am AEST) Just a few more thoughts based on my own experience going through the clerkship process and now being on the other side of it: In general, a law WAM of 75+ tends to put you in a strong position for HSF, Allens, and KWM, and a WAM of 70+ is typically considered competitive for the other firms. That said, these are absolutely not hard cut-offs, just rough guidelines. The perception that being at a Go8 university gives you an edge is outdated (as someone who went to one, this isn’t a cope). Firms are increasingly aware that university choice is often shaped by access and privilege at the high school level, and they don't moderate marks based on your university. A 75 is a 75, regardless of where you studied. For those who don’t believe me, if you stalk previous recent clerk cohorts at the big firms on LinkedIn, you’ll see a really sizeable portion did not study at a Go8. In terms of work experience, firms generally just want to see that you’ve had some – it doesn’t need to be with a T6 firm or even a legal role. They’re aware that highly sought-after paralegal experience can sometimes come down to nepotism or connections, and they don’t necessarily see it as a marker of pure merit (that is not to say you haven’t worked hard, it’s just something to keep in mind – on LinkedIn, you can see a lot of summer clerks have only worked in hospitality/retail before commencing). In fact, if you already have a T6 paralegal role or are perceived as highly likely to go to the best firms, some firms might choose not to invest time interviewing you (as for partners, they’re forgoing $1,000ph), as they’re trying to protect their yield and conversion rates. Furthermore, you also don’t need to have elite-level extracurriculars like Jessup mooting or Law Journal. For example, I know someone who received multiple top-tier offers whose application centred around their passion as a pole dancing instructor. Firms just want to see some engagement outside of your studies. Once you've met the basic thresholds – a reasonable WAM, some work experience, and some form of extracurricular involvement – one of the biggest differentiators becomes the quality of your written application. Crafting strong applications are an art in themselves and the writing style is quite specific and can take time to master, so please do not beat yourself up, it’s not a reflection on you or your capabilities or potential. It’s also true that each firm tends to look for a certain type of candidate – not just in terms of qualifications, but personality and “fit”. The best analogy I can offer is that it’s a bit like fraternity or sorority rush – while the process may seem uniform on the surface, each firm has its own distinct culture and tends to gravitate toward a specific “vibe” in candidates eg. one firm I'm thinking of tends to take nerds who are the type to genuinely enjoy talking about constitutional law at lunch, another firm I'm thinking of has a big work hard party hard culture and is quite jock-y in their intake etc.

author: mikoraiden
content: User #934539 48 posts mikoraiden I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPNfC posted 2025-Jul-22, 10:38 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNfC posted 2025-Jul-22, 10:38 am AEST I honestly do not believe Uni and WAM is everything, especially in 2025 lol. My friend who clerked at KWM last year went to MQ with a WAM of 74. While she had extensive legal experience at a Mid-tier firm and extra-curricular, she actually received offers from all of the T06 except Allens. I'm not too sure what recruiters are genuinely looking for, but thinking a firm only accepts a TO8 University (UTS isn't that far behind), is a pretty outdated view, I'm pretty sure Allens in the only firm that cares about that. Firms are trying to be more progressive and inclusive. My point essentially is don't think firms narrow down applicants based solely on your university or WAM (albeit your WAM is below 70, though I have heard of a clerk getting into B&B with a passing WAM – not sure at all how he made it).

author: Mike Wazowski
content: User #926634 40 posts Mike Wazowski Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPNf9 posted 2025-Jul-22, 10:47 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNf9 posted 2025-Jul-22, 10:47 am AEST In the interest of discussion, I disagree. UTS is known for having multiple choice exams and assignments vs USYD which literally has in-paper and sometimes closed book exams. The rigour of the academic process of these universities should not be discounted. Firms are 100% doing better to take into account disadvantage, which is great. However, I think to say that a 75 is a 75 regardless of where you study in a farce. I do largely agree with the following points, where you study alone will not discount you, however, I do think where you study is part of the consideration process. mikoraiden writes... My point essentially is don't think firms narrow down applicants based solely on your university or WAM (albeit your WAM is below 70, though I have heard of a clerk getting into B&B with a passing WAM – not sure at all how he made it) effystonem92 writes... Once you've met the basic thresholds – a reasonable WAM, some work experience, and some form of extracurricular involvement, one of the biggest differentiators becomes the quality of your written application. Crafting strong applications are an art in themselves and the writing style is quite specific and can take time to master, so please do not beat yourself up, it’s not a reflection on you or your capabilities or potential.

content: User #926736 15 posts anonunsw I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPNiw posted 2025-Jul-22, 11:15 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNiw posted 2025-Jul-22, 11:15 am AEST Just have the right last name and try not to drool on the interview table.

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPNiD posted 2025-Jul-22, 11:18 am AEST edited 2025-Jul-22, 11:25 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNiD posted 2025-Jul-22, 11:18 am AEST (edited 2025-Jul-22, 11:25 am AEST) Appreciate the spirit of discussion! As someone who attended a Go8 university and completed almost all assessments through in-person closed/open book exams, I completely understand the frustration and sense of unfairness that can arise when academic marks are not moderated consistently across institutions or formats. However, in practice, I don’t believe this discrepancy plays as significant a role in graduate recruitment outcomes as it may have in the past, even among top-tier firms. For example, here’s stats from a top tier firm who took in around 50 clerks last year. Less than 50% went to USYD/UNSW – still a sizeable amount, but not the domination that you’d once expect for the Sydney process. Over 30% came from universities like UTS, Macquarie, WSU, Wollongong and others, with the remainder from interstate or international institutions. This trend isn’t isolated to just one firm either – similar data patterns can be seen across other firms as well. Of course, this doesn’t mean your university doesn’t matter at all, but perhaps I oversimplified a bit in that it's moreso that the emphasis on institutional prestige isn’t quite as decisive as it once was.

author: sodapop104
content: User #934692 1 posts sodapop104 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPNBH posted 2025-Jul-22, 3:43 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNBH posted 2025-Jul-22, 3:43 pm AEST hey! was it a group email?

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPNCl posted 2025-Jul-22, 3:56 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNCl posted 2025-Jul-22, 3:56 pm AEST If it’s any comfort, remember, it only takes one. I know someone who’s always been an exceptional candidate with outstanding stats, but not the strongest when it comes to navigating written applications. When applying to the Big 4 accounting firms in their second year, they landed just one interview from a firm, but converted it to an offer. Same thing happened with their BBIB cycle in their third year – one interview, one offer. During clerkship season in their fourth year, they applied to over 20 firms and again received only one interview offer, which was from a T6, which they converted into a clerkship. And finally, when they applied to MBB in their final year, they only got one interview, and yes, turned it into an offer where they've now been working there happily for many years. It sounds beyond ridiculous, I couldn’t make it up even if I tried! I also have many friends who received “only” one or two interviews during clerkships, but still converted those into offers. It can feel incredibly disheartening, especially when you see others posting about having 10+ interviews, but this actually happens far more often than you’d think so please try not to lose hope!

author: lwoods420
content: User #934843 8 posts lwoods420 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPWjL posted 2025-Jul-29, 5:00 pm AEST edited 2025-Jul-29, 5:33 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPWjL posted 2025-Jul-29, 5:00 pm AEST (edited 2025-Jul-29, 5:33 pm AEST) Hi Guys, I know a lot of people are probably anxiously watching Whirlpool, so I thought I'd make a list based off what people in chat have said thus far and what I have heard. So far: - GNT: Psychometric Test released on 14 July (Rejection emails were sent too) - Bakers: Released on 14 July - NRF: Released on 17 July (No rejection email) - Turks: (Supposedly) Released 17 July - W&C: Video Interview released 17 July (Rejection emails sent) awaiting 2nd round - HFW: Released on 18 July (Rejection emails sent) - H&W: Released on 18 July (Rejection emails sent) - TG: Released 21 or 23 July (?) - MO: Released 21 July (?) - Corrs: Released 21 July (Rejection emails sent) - HSF: Released 21 July (Rejection emails sent) - B&B: Released 24 July (Rejection emails sent) - Minters: Released 24 July (Rejection emails sent) - Clifford Chance: Released 24 July (Rejection emails sent?) - KWM: Released 24 July (Notified by calling, unsure about rejections) - Maddocks: Released 25 July - Allens: Released 25 July (Rejection emails sent) - K&L Gates: (Supposedly) Released 28 July (No rejections as of yet) - DLA Piper: Released 28 July (Rejection emails sent) - Ashurst: Released 29 July (Rejection emails sent) - Gadens: Released 29 July (Rejection emails sent) Unconfirmed / Waiting (as of 5pm 29 July): - ClUtz (?) - A&O Shearman - Barry Nilsson - Hamers - HWL Ebsworth - JWS (?) - Jones Day (?) - McIntyre Legal - Morgan + English - McR - Clyde & Co Best of luck to everyone else waiting or to those heading into the interview stage – you got it!

author: effystonem92
content: User #871309 309 posts effystonem92 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPXh1 posted 2025-Jul-30, 5:18 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPXh1 posted 2025-Jul-30, 5:18 pm AEST For G+T VI, IMHO, be ready for at least one of the questions to be a more social or unexpected question, something a bit off the beaten path. A few years ago, for example, one of the questions was 'What is your most embarrassing moment?'. They tend to include a question like that every year to showcase your personality and see how well you can think on your feet, rather than flogging x4 standard behaviourals. That said, I'm speaking as someone who's no longer directly involved so this may longer be accurate, and unfortunately, you're not likely to get many people offering tips or giving you a heads-up advantage on online forums which is understandable, but hopefully this is somewhat of help.

author: mikoraiden
content: User #934539 48 posts mikoraiden I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP2V7 posted 2025-Aug-5, 11:17 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP2V7 posted 2025-Aug-5, 11:17 am AEST +Barry Nilsson

author: overthinker123
content: User #889088 45 posts overthinker123 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP24R posted 2025-Aug-5, 1:24 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP24R posted 2025-Aug-5, 1:24 pm AEST mikoraiden writes... it's a written assessment and role play – any advice (even from other firms) would mean a lot! Haven't done C&C AC, but general advice. Brush up on your affidavit skills, email etiquette and legal language. For any group assessment, do not worry about being talked over and focus on getting your point across. Firms prefer those that are collaborative and open-minded as opposed to those that are dismissive. If it's a negotiation exercise, they are not looking at seeing you 'win' but how collaborative each party is in approaching a solution that is in both clients' interests. Not sure if that helps, but I hope you got some insight.

author: leitpg
content: User #932680 84 posts leitpg Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOj80 posted 2025-Apr-22, 9:03 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOj80 posted 2025-Apr-22, 9:03 pm AEST Guys I need urgent help! I have a background in Computer Science/Data and applied to three Deloitte grad streams: Data Analytics Engineering & AI Sustainability & Industrial Engineering I’m mainly interested in the first two, and only applied for the Sustainability stream as a backup/practice. I submitted my applications fairly late. So far, only the Sustainability stream has progressed (currently at Assessment Centre stage), while the other two have been stuck at “Psychometric testing completed” since the 14th of this month. Today I got a call from a Deloitte staff member inviting me to the AC for the Sustainability stream, but she also mentioned that my other two applications will be put on hold. Does anyone know exactly when that hold kicks in? Was it triggered when I received the VI invitation on the 14th? (If that’s the case, maybe the other two still had a chance but now it might be too late?) Or does the hold start now, only because they’ve called me for the AC? Given this situation, would it be too risky to politely decline the AC invite for the Sustainability stream and hope my preferred streams (Data Analytics or Eng & AI) still have a chance to move forward? Would really appreciate any insights or advice from someone who’s gone through something similar!!

author: kevin2025gp

Does this mean, even if the portal says application unsuccessful, we may still receive AC?

author: Graddff
content: User #931756 105 posts Graddff Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOkp5 posted 2025-Apr-23, 9:51 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOkp5 posted 2025-Apr-23, 9:51 am AEST kevin2025gp writes... content: User #932091 38 posts gradroleplsssssssss Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOrgj posted 2025-Apr-30, 3:44 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOrgj posted 2025-Apr-30, 3:44 pm AEST got this email this morning btw – We know you’re probably wondering what’s happening with your application. We’re busy reviewing applications, which we hope you can appreciate, as one of Australia's most popular graduate employers this takes our team a lot of time, but we’re working as fast as we can. Hold tight and best of luck!

author: Phirlwool
content: User #912858 3 posts Phirlwool I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOA8B posted 2025-May-7, 10:10 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOA8B posted 2025-May-7, 10:10 pm AEST ACs run from mid April until the end of June and teams are randomly allocated dates. If the team you applied for is scheduled towards the end, your application it won't be looked at till then. Just because you haven't heard anything or your application status hasn't changed, it doesn't mean you aren't in the process anymore. There are multiple M&A teams that each have their own AC.

content: User #914149 57 posts pleshiremee Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOerk posted 2025-Apr-16, 4:30 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOerk posted 2025-Apr-16, 4:30 am AEST People who attended PwC's AC before, for the group interview did you present your group's work in front of other groups? I only had virtual AC and we got breakout rooms on Zoom so kinda nervous if I'll have to do that...

author: chilling_25
content: User #911741 101 posts chilling_25 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOeJI posted 2025-Apr-16, 11:50 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOeJI posted 2025-Apr-16, 11:50 am AEST anyone received ac for sydney – grads? except for audit

author: golddigger01
content: User #927600 41 posts golddigger01 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgOeJ1 posted 2025-Apr-16, 11:53 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOeJ1 posted 2025-Apr-16, 11:53 am AEST @pleshiremee No, we didn't have to present in front of other groups. They broke us into groups of 4-5 and allocated us to small rooms on the floor where 2 PwC employees from that team conducted the group interview. They explained the case brief (for which they sent supplementary resources prior to the AC day) and gave us 45 minutes to work together and come up with solutions/ideas to present. Then after presenting, they asked a bunch of questions but I'm pretty sure they really only assess how well you worked together as a group/how much of a team player you were. According to the feedback I got after, they mark your group and individual interview both out of 5, so total out of 10.

I think they are slowly sending out rejection email. It's better to just accept the result and move on at this point because today is the last day in the office for the Easter break and I think they are not back until next Tuesday. My friend also told me that PWC this year moved their AC invite earlier to avoid people being poached by other big 4 as they are all finalising already.

author: imsosickofAC
content: User #933228 21 posts imsosickofAC I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOInm posted 2025-May-15, 6:21 pm AEST edited 2025-May-15, 6:36 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOInm posted 2025-May-15, 6:21 pm AEST (edited 2025-May-15, 6:36 pm AEST) From my understanding. It's really based on the team and how fast they want to process you. i.e. they might have the meeting to decide who to choose straight away after the interview or the following week. If anyone is reading this and is worried because the firms have not contacted them yet, DO NOT WORRY. From what I know the process can take up to many days, but most likely you will find out within 7- 10 business days (and some cases maybe longer).

author: imsosickofAC
content: User #933228 21 posts imsosickofAC I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgOInN posted 2025-May-15, 6:29 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgOInN posted 2025-May-15, 6:29 pm AEST Group Interview: I made sure I talked a lot, but also made sure that I asked people to contribute as well. Interview: IMO the interview was only 30 mins, which is really short. But the people who interviewed me did ask many follow up questions and seem interested in me. General: Also, I am a G08 student with a borderline credit WAM (I've failed 3 classes so far) and still received 2 Vaccies offer from Big4. So if anyone reading this thinks that they aren't good enough, don't be too hard on yourself.

author: smbb
content: User #836476 94 posts smbb Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPCNX posted 2025-Jul-10, 3:06 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPCNX posted 2025-Jul-10, 3:06 pm AEST you wouldn't have missed a call without them first sending you the psychometric assessment, you successfully completing that, and then them sending you an email for you to click into and schedule a phone interview. so just sit tight and wait to hear back on the above first.

Most people get it after I honestly thought it was normal because Macquarie's recruitment process outlines that after submitting the application (step 1), there will be an interview to find more info about me (step 2). Then step 3 is described as psychometric assessment. If I pass the assessment, it says I will have more interviews (step 4). Step 5 is the offer and step 6 is reference checking: https://www.macquarie.com/au/ en/careers/recruitment-process.html

thread_title: Macquarie Group Summer Internship 2025/2026 -  Graduate programs
author: cuckoo1999
content: User #934384 64 posts cuckoo1999 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP7Kz posted 2025-Aug-10, 11:56 am AEST edited 2025-Aug-10, 1:19 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP7Kz posted 2025-Aug-10, 11:56 am AEST (edited 2025-Aug-10, 1:19 pm AEST) kesshayati writes... Didn’t even make it to the phone or psychometric stage. It could be that there was something that you didn't meet with the first stage of the application. Usually how it goes is: fill in details about yourself (like uploading resume, etc) -> psych assessment -> phone screen -> AC -> Offer. The psych and phone could sometimes be swapped in that process. More info here: https://www.macquarie.com/au/ en/careers/recruitment-process.html The fact that you didn't get the psych assessment/phone interview may mean that there was some requirement you didn't meet when you were filling in the initial application details. I am not sure what that would be though. Are you a penultimate student? Also, when did you apply? If you applied closer to the closing date of the apps, you have a lower chance of moving forward than those who applied earlier because they look at applicants at a rolling basis. So if you did apply late, then you are in risk being overlooked if decisions have already been made. Anyway, you should contact them to ask why you were rejected. So you can know what requirements you are not meeting (if any) or if it's because you applied closer to the end date (if you did) or if it's due to something else that you can fix/get around for future apps.

thread_title: ASA Nuclear Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: The Narrator
content: User #452549 81 posts The Narrator Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPQfX posted 2025-Jul-25, 12:07 pm AEST edited 2025-Jul-25, 12:17 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPQfX posted 2025-Jul-25, 12:07 pm AEST (edited 2025-Jul-25, 12:17 pm AEST) I dont know what the process is, as far as I am aware it is something similar to that, maybe with some notes about the interview and what our strengths were? i know for merit lists, we are ranked. Pools may have some ranking to an extent (ie pool for highly suitable, suitable) and they go from highly suitable first but im unsure how they pick from the pool itself. good luck to us all. eidt: "At this stage, candidates will be matched to suitable positions in order of merit and offered a position subject to successfully attaining a NV1 Clearance." It appears this pool is more of a ranked list?

thread_title: ASA Nuclear Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: apshubber
content: User #911685 46 posts apshubber Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPQh5 posted 2025-Jul-25, 12:41 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPQh5 posted 2025-Jul-25, 12:41 pm AEST O.P. yeah I think it’s a ranked list based off whatever (most likely just CV) and they’ll go down in order to make verbal offers I believe the reason it’s a merit list is so that if someone declines an offer (very possible as they may opt for other agencies/departments), HR would have reserves to make offers to – hence offers are being made on a rolling basis from late July to early August.

thread_title: ASA Nuclear Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: anonymous moose
content: User #935290 9 posts anonymous moose I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgQbfN posted 2025-Aug-14, 11:38 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgQbfN posted 2025-Aug-14, 11:38 am AEST tbh I dunno about merit either lol I was sure I hadn't got a role. Since the website says that the merit pool wasn't ranked I guess they look at resumes and see where you might fit in? I have an engineering background in renewable energy and enviro stuff and I mentioned some remediation/waste/lifecycle stuff in my interview which got some good reactions. My one on one interview was kinda mid (needed some prompts from the Hudson interviewer) but I was super keen on the job and I think I did well in the question about why you wanna work in ASA because I was able to name specific teams/areas I wanted to work in. I could have improved my interview by talking about the lessons learnt from my STAR examples, not just stating them and their results. I have no nuclear background, and I only had a consulting vacationer experience and my current private industry job (not super relevant but has transferrable skills).

thread_title: ASA Nuclear Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: Pacific7163
content: User #934846 14 posts Pacific7163 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgQbgn posted 2025-Aug-14, 11:49 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgQbgn posted 2025-Aug-14, 11:49 am AEST How I'm guessing it works is while other agencies go MP -> VO, and then if they get a rejection they give the VO to the next person, how ASA is doing it is MP -> OSA -> VO, but if someone fails the OSA or rejects the VO then they send the OSA to the next person. Website says that OSA takes 4-6 weeks so it extends the process a lot so I'd hold out hope for now. But I am just making an educated guess.

thread_title: ASA Nuclear Graduate Program -  Graduate programs

content: User #911685 46 posts apshubber Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgQbhc posted 2025-Aug-14, 11:58 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgQbhc posted 2025-Aug-14, 11:58 am AEST O.P. Pacific7163 writes... Website says that OSA takes 4-6 weeks so it extends the process a lot so I'd hold out hope for now. But I am just making an educated guess. I feel like it's OSA for the STEM stream given the email says you "may" need to undertake it. Makes sense given STEM is the crown jewel for ASA whereas Policy & Corporate would be dealing with less sensitive matters.

content: User #452549 81 posts The Narrator Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgQbid posted 2025-Aug-14, 12:12 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgQbid posted 2025-Aug-14, 12:12 pm AEST did they tell you how many people made it to the merit pool. I actually didnt feel like i did well in my individual section, kind of got grilled a lot and im just like ok im done, but still got to merit pool. but to think they sent the forms 2 days after your AC, kind of feels like you topped their list straight up. i need to live with the fact that i made it to two merit pools and didnt get an offer from either now :(

thread_title: ASA Nuclear Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: anonymous moose
content: User #935290 9 posts anonymous moose I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgQbki posted 2025-Aug-14, 12:40 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgQbki posted 2025-Aug-14, 12:40 pm AEST got no info on merit pool selection processes or how many were in there (but I also didn't ask during the phone call so someone else may find out). dw though I tried a STEM cadetship last year and got merit listed but no offer. I also tried MDBA several science and tech departments and didn't get past the assessment so getting merit listed is actually really good. un-ranked merit lists are still kinda based on luck though I reckon, just depends on who looks at your resume at the time – ASA is also trying to get a diverse bunch of people so maybe they have only a set amount of positions for science vs eng vs legal etc.

content: User #933855 1 posts OoOoOoOo I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPaly posted 2025-Jun-11, 6:03 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPaly posted 2025-Jun-11, 6:03 pm AEST +1 Interview Honestly a bit surprised I got past the group stage because I was on the quieter side. Looks like as long as you added to the discussion a bit then you're given a 'pass' by the facilitators to move onto the next stage Does anyone know if merit pools will be used, or will offers be sent out directly?

author: IMPERIAL745
content: User #930487 43 posts IMPERIAL745 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPayX posted 2025-Jun-11, 9:12 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPayX posted 2025-Jun-11, 9:12 pm AEST @OoOoOoOo Afaik everybody who is suitable (including preferred candidates) get added to the merit pool. After this happens, people in merit pool will be asked their preferences on where/what team they want to work with. After all of this is done the preferred candidates will get contacted for offers, and then until Octoberish others in the merit pool may be offered as well.

author: IMPERIAL745
content: User #930487 43 posts IMPERIAL745 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPay6 posted 2025-Jun-11, 9:13 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPay6 posted 2025-Jun-11, 9:13 pm AEST It basically looks like the merit pool is used by everybody so that they can facilitate their preference system, which makes sense. Some preferred candidates could get offered for a team/location that they didn't want, which would waste defence's time.

author: broseph33
content: User #928678 61 posts broseph33 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPZVV posted 2025-Aug-2, 10:51 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPZVV posted 2025-Aug-2, 10:51 am AEST I hope the process is faster this year, but last year, the Cadetship didn't finalise people in the merit pool until like October and hadn't started verbal offers until like late November/early December. The ones that didn't get any positions and remained in the Merit Pool didn't get notified until like Feb 2025. Their admin/hr team is useless at recruiting and I wonder how many people turned them down because they couldn't wait infinitely long for an offer, especially when everyone else already has their candidates locked in by now.

author: IMPERIAL745
content: User #930487 43 posts IMPERIAL745 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPZW0 posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:13 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPZW0 posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:13 am AEST yeah I noticed that looking at last year's forum, but it looks like they addressed it this year with the merit pool in august and offers between late august and october. So even if you get offered in october you still have enough time to get clearance before the program starts in february. I think another issue they had last year was too many people in the merit pool, might also explain why group assessment and interview happened in separate stages, they are probably trying to minimise the amount of people in the merit pool so they have less to deal with/it will be easier to give out offers.

author: IMPERIAL745
content: User #930487 43 posts IMPERIAL745 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPZW5 posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:15 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPZW5 posted 2025-Aug-2, 11:15 am AEST Oh and another thing, it looks like last year they didnt have any "agency nomination" when they got to merit pool, I believe that is another measure that defence implemented this year to ensure that people get offered for what they want and that time isnt wasted with offers being declined (even though some offers will probably still get declined by people due to the length of the recruitment and others already having offers from other places).

author: broseph33
content: User #928678 61 posts broseph33 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP2kc posted 2025-Aug-4, 6:06 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP2kc posted 2025-Aug-4, 6:06 pm AEST I wouldn't put too much stock in their timelines, especially if you're weighing up other offers. As offers last year were also meant to come out around August from memory, but nothing happened until like October/November. Not sure how it's running this year, but last year you chose the groups you were interested in when you applied (i.e. if you wanted DSTG, you would put down DSTG as part of your application and your group assessment/interview was also with that group). But yeah hope for you guys that they stick to the timelines this year, as there's nothing worse than not knowing, especially not knowing when to expect an offer either.

author: cuckoo1999
content: User #934384 64 posts cuckoo1999 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPCoW posted 2025-Jul-10, 10:12 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPCoW posted 2025-Jul-10, 10:12 am AEST When you say OA, do you also mean both the game based assessment and the personality questionnaire? If so, if you haven't received anything back within 24 hours, I am pretty sure it means you have been rejected. Checked the last years intake and they apparently received their outcomes/updates after each OA within 24 hours. And even after some hours E.g., after filling in the application on the 5th I think, pretty sure within the next 24/48 hours, I got the invitation to complete the game based assessment. Then after some hours later, I got the invitation to do the personality questionnaire. I did the personality questionnaire yesterday. I know it hasn't been 24 hours yet but I received invitations to the OA tests within a few hours, like between 7am-8am. And checked my emails today, no emails. So I think I have been rejected based on my personality responses. But who knows, maybe it's different this year but if we are going from last year's intake, if you don't get a response on your OA tests within 24/48 hours, then most likely you have been rejected. Can someone who got a response after the personality questionnaire confirm? Did you get a response/update within 24/48 hours? Or did it take longer than that? I will give an update if I hear anything back.

thread_title: 2025/2026 ANZ Summer Intern Program -  Graduate programs
author: cuckoo1999
content: User #934384 64 posts cuckoo1999 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPE8E posted 2025-Jul-12, 11:10 pm AEST edited 2025-Jul-12, 11:27 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPE8E posted 2025-Jul-12, 11:10 pm AEST (edited 2025-Jul-12, 11:27 pm AEST) I think you should expect to receive the game based assessments within 48 hours after the application. I got it within 48 hours. If you haven't, try emailing them. The next stage after submitting the app consists of you recording yourself where you need to draw experiences from work/school/from whatever to answer scenario based questions. Then after the recordings, you will play game based assessments. They are easy to do, they are not highly technical but you have a time limit and you have to try and do them as much as you can within the time limit. But don't rush because you want to get them correct too, do them as correct and quickly as you can. Just make sure you understand the rules of the games. Then after the game based assessments, you should get a personality questionnaire within 48 hours. After completing the personality questionnaire, according to their site, the next stage is interview prep but I am not sure what that is. After that, it's face to face interview. I am not sure when we are supposed to get the interview prep after the personality questionnaire. I have done the personality questionnaire but haven't heard anything back. If someone has gotten an email after the personality questionnaire, it would be cool to know here when you got an email. Cos that would then pretty much confirm that people who didn't get a response within X hours means that they are not moving forward. Oh and this is specifically for the technology stream, so I am not sure if the process and the timing of things are different for other streams.

thread_title: 2025/2026 ANZ Summer Intern Program -  Graduate programs
author: cuckoo1999
content: User #934384 64 posts cuckoo1999 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPHQm posted 2025-Jul-16, 1:15 am AEST edited 2025-Jul-16, 5:54 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPHQm posted 2025-Jul-16, 1:15 am AEST (edited 2025-Jul-16, 5:54 pm AEST) vegetables writes... Am I the only person who had to do the HireVue, game-based assessments, and personality questionnaire all at the same time? Did it last Thursday and haven't received an update since (Melbourne tech). If you scroll down to "Application Process" in here: https://www.anz.com.au/career s/career-programs/summer-internship/ , stage 2 is digital interview and game based assessment. The game based assessment consists of 4 games. 3 of the games are testing your technical skills. But the 4th game is a personality quiz. If you passed stage 2, then you should get an invite to do the personality questionnaire (stage 3). So you have to do a personality quiz in stage 2, which is represented as a game but you have to do another personality quiz in stage 3. So, have you done both the personality quizzes from stage 2 and stage 3? If so, you got them together in the same email? If so, that's not the usual process. Regardless, as long as you have done both personality quizzes, I think you just need to wait till the applications close to get the next update on the apps. (unless someone has been updated after completing stage 3). I think the usual process is: if stage 2 is a pass -> receive stage 3 invitation within 24/48 hours -> wait until apps closed to receive an update on the app. Not completely sure, just what I think.

thread_title: 2025/2026 ANZ Summer Intern Program -  Graduate programs
author: cuckoo1999
content: User #934384 64 posts cuckoo1999 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP3iQ posted 2025-Aug-5, 5:12 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP3iQ posted 2025-Aug-5, 5:12 pm AEST cuckoo1999 writes... Not sure if ANZ looks at applicants at a rolling basis though. In regards to what I said, don't think they look at applicants on a rolling basis. From ANZ FAQs: "I’ve already completed all of the assessments and the HireVue interview. When can I expect an update on my application? Our team waits until applications close, and then gives time to the last applicants to complete their assessments before we assess all applications." So they assess all applicants until it closes, meaning applicants who applied closer to the due date have the same/equal chances as those who applied earlier in moving forward

author: ConfusedPeanut
content: User #934294 4 posts ConfusedPeanut I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPZ6d posted 2025-Aug-2, 2:38 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPZ6d posted 2025-Aug-2, 2:38 pm AEST I emailed and they said to check back in a week if I haven't heard anything How did your interview go?? author: Researcher
content: User #933121 52 posts Researcher Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP0R0 posted 2025-Aug-3, 11:46 am AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP0R0 posted 2025-Aug-3, 11:46 am AEST O.P. Yeah I thought so. When they called me on Monday for progressing to VI, they booked me in straight away for the same week and did RC (which they said they do to all interviewees) the following day. If you haven’t been contacted this week I believe everyone still has a good chance. Goodluck!! They were all super nice and understanding so it’s honestly hard to tell. I think I did pretty ok for my interview. But I guess we’d have to wait and see 5 weeks from now. Good luck everyone!

author: poet_111
content: User #935055 6 posts poet_111 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP32m posted 2025-Aug-6, 1:14 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP32m posted 2025-Aug-6, 1:14 pm AEST Hello, I had my interview on Monday. They told me that they still have ~4 weeks of interviews to go. I emailed asking when we find out outcomes and they said within the next fortnight. As per annual reports, their graduate intake is as follows: 2023-24: 11 2022-23: 26 2021-22: 11 2020-21: 6 2019-20: 13 2018-19: 19 2017-18: 18 2016-17: 14 2015-16: 21 2014-15: 8 SOURCE: https://www.transparency.gov. au/portfolio-entities-compan ies/health/australian-institute-of-health-and-welfare There seems to be no pattern except that they keep it below 30. I'm glad I stumbled upon this forum. Never knew it existed as I am not from Australia lol.

author: Researcher
content: User #933121 52 posts Researcher Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP6vJ posted 2025-Aug-8, 6:25 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6vJ posted 2025-Aug-8, 6:25 pm AEST O.P. Fingers crossed!! This is one of my top preferences and would love to find out if I get in or not sooner. Strange though how we get to find out before all the interviews are done..? I also did biomedical sciences but a MPH after. So happy to be done and excited to work FT

author: poet_111
content: User #935055 6 posts poet_111 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP7ax posted 2025-Aug-9, 3:22 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP7ax posted 2025-Aug-9, 3:22 pm AEST The people that conduct the interviews are CBR recruitment (external to AIHW) and they have 4 weeks of interviews left. They conduct interviews for more than just AIHW; I believe they do it for “Australian public services” (APS) as a whole. Hence, there are 4 weeks of APS interviews left. The AIHW interviews will be finishing up within the next fortnight like they told me by email. So AIHW isn’t going to be telling outcomes as interviews are being conducted. Based off of previous AIHW and APS threads, I assume our interview answers get sent to various AIHW departments and we get ranked by the department heads and then “match” into one. In 2022-23 there were 45 people interviews by AIHW and a >50% recruitment rate that year so I’d assume anyone interviewed has a solid chance for offers. Did you apply for any other grad roles? I applied for CSL 2026 grad program but I won’t hear back from them till early September lol

author: Researcher
content: User #933121 52 posts Researcher Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP7NG posted 2025-Aug-10, 1:17 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP7NG posted 2025-Aug-10, 1:17 pm AEST O.P. Ohhh okay that makes more sense. The people who interviewed me – 3 were working for AIHW and the other was a scribe. I’m guessing the scribe was the CBR recruitment? I applied for various APS jobs including dep of justice WA, services Australia, NDIA and AIHW. I’ve done ¾ interviews, merit pool for services AUS and should be getting news about offers soon I hope! It’s been a long process so fingers crossed. Good luck for CSL. I hear that’s a great place to work for (friends and current manager did an internship with them).

author: kids-ranqe
content: User #933908 24 posts kids-ranqe I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP6gq posted 2025-Aug-8, 3:06 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6gq posted 2025-Aug-8, 3:06 pm AEST Thank you for your patience as we work through the next steps for the 2026 John Holland Graduate Program. We had planned to share your application outcome by today, 8 August. However, we have received some new requests from some of our project teams looking for graduates in 2026. This means we’ll need a little more time before providing you with a final update. We understand waiting can be challenging, and we truly appreciate your understanding. We are now aiming to provide you with an update by Wednesday, 14 August. Thank you again for your interest in joining our graduate program and for bearing with us during this short delay. All the best, The John Holland Team
