author: babyclerk
content: User #917742 9 posts babyclerk I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPJfe posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:15 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPJfe posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:15 pm AEST it seems everyone got a referee check, so no decisions made?

author: hat27
content: User #690891 49 posts hat27 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPJfG posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:21 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPJfG posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:21 pm AEST it seems everyone got a referee check, so no decisions made? What gives you that impression? I don’t actually know but logically it wouldn’t make much sense to extend a referee request to everyone after 5 weeks since the AC. The email does say no selection decisions have been made and it’s just needed for the rest of the process so I would think this was the next stage in slimming down the candidate pool before making offers? I could be completely wrong though. Until someone posts they didn’t receive the referee check email, we’ll never really know.

author: HelloWorld99
content: User #933624 16 posts HelloWorld99 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPJf1 posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:26 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPJf1 posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:26 pm AEST Typically they would only send referee checks to candidates that have progressed past the assessment centre, so would imagine this reflects progression to the next stage. Like hat27 was saying, going to be difficult to tell unless someone specifies they’ve been rejected.

content: User #933688 4 posts sugar7oaf I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPJh3 posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:54 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPJh3 posted 2025-Jul-17, 2:54 pm AEST +1 Referoo From what I’m aware. The email saying no selection has been made is because there is still security clearance and merit pooling to be done. So this specific email is not a grantee of an offer (so don’t quit your current job basically). But it’s some form of progression at least.

author: GradSeeker2025
content: User #910593 216 posts GradSeeker2025 Forum Regular reference: whrl.pl/RgPLV0 posted 2025-Jul-20, 5:48 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPLV0 posted 2025-Jul-20, 5:48 pm AEST I’ll be applying again next year. You’re honestly not too old, at all. Graduate programs are extremely diverse. People in their 40s+ get admittance in government graduate programs.

author: HelloWorld99
content: User #933624 16 posts HelloWorld99 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPMvt posted 2025-Jul-21, 1:24 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMvt posted 2025-Jul-21, 1:24 pm AEST I completed my undergraduate degree a couple of years ago and have been working in private sector since then. While this is my first time applying, you should definitely keep reapplying within the 5-year window after your degree. I know many people have reapplied multiple times before being accepted so definitely go for it!

author: grad294729
content: User #934687 1 posts grad294729 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPNAx posted 2025-Jul-22, 3:26 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPNAx posted 2025-Jul-22, 3:26 pm AEST Hi GradSeeker2025 and hellothere12389, sorry to hear that you didn’t progress. I would highly recommend applying again if you are passionate about working at DFAT. This was not my first attempt and I learned a lot from my previous application which helped me to progress further this time around. From what I’ve heard most people need to apply 2-3 times before they are successful so don’t feel disheartened at all!! In the meantime, I’d highly recommend looking at Austrade’s grad program. It’s open now and allows you to work in international trade/International relations without moving to Canberra. You will also learn skills that are highly relevant to DFAT meaning it provides an excellent launchpad if you do intend to apply for DFAT again! Here’s the link if you are interested: https://www.austrade.gov.au/e n/careers-at-austrade/graduate-program

content: User #690891 49 posts hat27 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP6oZ posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:10 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6oZ posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:10 pm AEST +1 Merit Pool

author: hat27
content: User #690891 49 posts hat27 Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgP6o7 posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:11 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6o7 posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:11 pm AEST Do we know if everyone gets merit pooled first or do some people get formal offers initially? I think from the phrasing of the email you get merit pooled first and recommendations for employment are made from there. No idea how large the merit pool is relative to the amount of offers made.

author: HelloWorld99
content: User #933624 16 posts HelloWorld99 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP6o9 posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:12 pm AEST edited 2025-Aug-8, 5:40 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6o9 posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:12 pm AEST (edited 2025-Aug-8, 5:40 pm AEST) +1 Merit Pool! Looks like everyone gets merit pooled first (they have an internal ranking list of preferred candidates). My estimated guess is merit pool is typically 15-20% higher than final cohort (maybe about 100 and they accept 75-90). This accounts for withdrawals, failed clearances and people who accept other offers (numbers are just guesses but likely similar to other APS department figures). Based on previous years there will be an academic transcript check and then epack for security clearance. As long as nothing damning comes up there, top ranked candidates receives conditional employment offer pending clearance. Once clearance has been completed, successful candidates will receive final employment offer. May be wrong about any of the above details, this is just from searching through every pre-existing forum. Hope this helps!

author: HelloWorld99
content: User #933624 16 posts HelloWorld99 I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgP6q3 posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:36 pm AEST edited 2025-Aug-8, 5:43 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgP6q3 posted 2025-Aug-8, 5:36 pm AEST (edited 2025-Aug-8, 5:43 pm AEST) I made a mistake with part of this. Process will likely be in a couple of weeks there will be a first batch of recommendations for employment (conditional offers) for top ranked candidates. Small portion of candidates will receive no offer of employment. These candidates will be kept on the bench in case offers in the first batch of preferred candidates fall through, creating additional openings, hence why merit pool extends 18 months. Alternatively, candidates who are suitable, but not preferred could be offered roles in other APS departments. Security clearance is expensive so they typically only do it for preferred candidates.

thread_title: NSW Government Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: pickle brine
content: User #933750 20 posts pickle brine I'm new here, please be nice reference: whrl.pl/RgPMDQ posted 2025-Jul-21, 3:43 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMDQ posted 2025-Jul-21, 3:43 pm AEST Just received a very generic reply to my enquiry on whether or not they were using past results for the OA and why they would be assessing data that may no longer reflect our current capabilities or circumstances. "Thank you for contacting us regarding the 2026 NSW Government Graduate Program. The program received an exceptionally high number of submissions, with a limited number of places in the next stage of the recruitment process. After careful consideration of your online application and situational judgement question responses, your application was not progressed to the next stage. Due to the volume of applications, we are unable to provide individual feedback on outcomes, however we appreciate the time and effort you invested We wish you all the best in your future career search and encourage you to look on I work for NSW to find other opportunities in the NSW Government."

thread_title: NSW Government Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: wontellya
content: User #403498 60 posts wontellya Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPMXp posted 2025-Jul-21, 8:54 pm AEST edited 2025-Jul-21, 9:24 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMXp posted 2025-Jul-21, 8:54 pm AEST (edited 2025-Jul-21, 9:24 pm AEST) For this test do they consider absolute values, so that there is a cutoff, and if someone is above it passes to the next stage , no matter how many applicants? Or is it rather relative values, where applicants are ranked by result and then a certain percentage of them (so a fixed number of applicants) goes to the next stage?

thread_title: NSW Government Graduate Program -  Graduate programs
author: wontellya
content: User #403498 60 posts wontellya Participant reference: whrl.pl/RgPMYb posted 2025-Jul-21, 9:12 pm AEST edited 2025-Jul-21, 10:05 pm AEST ref: whrl.pl/RgPMYb posted 2025-Jul-21, 9:12 pm AEST (edited 2025-Jul-21, 10:05 pm AEST) And how long should one expect to wait to get an answer? Do they contact other candidates first and see if they do any better than the ones who already took the test? Probably it works this way They have a cutoff. if not enough people have reached the cutoff, then they get in touch with candidates who were told they are still being considered. If those candidates perform better, then they get the spot. Otherwise the original candidates who didn’t make the cutoff get the spots – or maybe they don’t and less candidates progress to the next stage (perhaps up to a number) If the above is correct, emails will be sent tomorrow to “still being considered” candidates who will be invited to take the test by Thursday, and on Friday everyone will be informed of whether they’re in or not
